{{short description|False information spread deliberately to deceive}} {{Other uses|Disinformation (disambiguation)}} {{distinguish|Misinformation}} {{use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[File:Disinformation vs Misinformation.jpg|thumb|300px|Graphic showing differences between disinformation, [[misinformation]], and [[hoax]]]] '''Disinformation''' is false information spread deliberately to deceive.<ref name=pacepa /><ref name=bittman1985 /><ref name=shultzgodson /> The English word [[wikt:disinformation|''disinformation'']] is a [[loan translation]] of the Russian [[wikt:дезинформация|''dezinformatsiya'']],<ref name=pacepa /><ref name=bittman1985 /><ref name=shultzgodson /> derived from the title of a [[KGB]] [[black propaganda]] department.<ref name=jowett /> The book ''[[Disinformation (book)|Disinformation]]'' documents that [[Joseph Stalin]] coined the term, giving it a French-sounding name to falsely claim it had a Western origin.<ref name=pacepa />
Russian use began with a "special disinformation office" in 1923.<ref name=manningromerstein /> Disinformation was defined in ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' (1952) as "false information with the intention to deceive public opinion".<ref name=pacepa /><ref name=bittman1985 /><ref name=adamtaylor /> [[Operation INFEKTION]] was a Soviet disinformation campaign to influence opinion that the U.S. invented [[AIDS]].<ref name=pacepa /><ref name=adamtaylor /><ref name=usstate /> The U.S. did not actively counter disinformation until 1980, when a [[Forgery as covert operation|fake document]] reported that the U.S. supported [[apartheid]].<ref name=jmichaelwaller />
The word ''disinformation'' did not appear in English dictionaries until the late-1980s.<ref name=pacepa /><ref name=bittman1985 /> English use increased in 1986, after revelations that the [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|Reagan Administration]] engaged in disinformation against [[Libya]]n leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]].<ref name=biagi /> By 1990 it was pervasive in U.S. politics;<ref name=davidmartin /> and by 2001 referred generally to lying and [[propaganda]].<ref name=heinemann /><ref name=cunningham />
==Etymology and early usage== The English word ''disinformation'', which did not appear in dictionaries until the late-1980s, is a translation of the Russian [[wikt:дезинформация|дезинформация]], [[transliterated]] as ''dezinformatsiya''.<ref name=bittman1985>{{citation|first=Ladislav|last=Bittman|authorlink=Lawrence Martin-Bittman|title=The KGB and Soviet Disinformation: An Insider's View|year=1985|isbn=978-0-08-031572-0|publisher=Pergamon-Brassey's|pages=49–50|title-link=The KGB and Soviet Disinformation}}</ref><ref name=adamtaylor /><ref name=pacepa /> Where [[misinformation]] refers to inaccuracies that stem from error, disinformation is deliberate falsehood promulgated by design.<ref name=jowett /> Misinformation can be used to define disinformation—when known misinformation is purposefully and intentionally disseminated.<ref name=golbeck>{{citation|pages=19–20|title=Computing with Social Trust|editor1-first=Jennifer|editor1-last=Golbeck|year=2008|isbn=978-1-84800-355-2|publisher=Springer|series=Human-Computer Interaction Series}}</ref> [[Front group]]s are a form of disinformation, as they fraudulently mislead as to their actual controllers.<ref name=eugeneasamier>{{citation|title=Secrecy and Tradecraft in Educational Administration: The Covert Side of Educational Life|page=176|first=Eugene A.|last=Samier|series=Routledge Research in Education|year=2014|isbn= 978-0-415-81681-6|publisher=Routledge}}</ref> Disinformation tactics can lead to [[Blowback (intelligence)|blowback]], unintended negative problems due to the strategy, for example [[defamation]] lawsuits or damage to reputation.<ref name=eugeneasamier /> Disinformation is primarily prepared by government [[intelligence agency|intelligence agencies]].<ref name=jangoldman>{{citation|title=Words of Intelligence: A Dictionary|first=Jan|last=Goldman|chapter=Disinformation|isbn=978-0-8108-5641-7|year=2006|publisher=Scarecrow Press|page=43}}</ref>
Usage of the term related to a Russian tactical weapon started in 1923, when the Deputy Chairman of the [[KGB]]-precursor the [[State Political Directorate]] (GPU), [[Józef Unszlicht]], called for the foundation of "a special disinformation office to conduct active intelligence operations".<ref name=manningromerstein>{{citation|pages=82–83|title=Historical Dictionary of American Propaganda|author1=Martin J. Manning |author2=Herbert Romerstein|chapter=Disinformation|year=2004|isbn=978-0-313-29605-5|publisher=Greenwood}}</ref> The GPU was the first organization in the Soviet Union to utilize the term disinformation for their intelligence tactics.<ref name=annsenn>{{citation|page=25|title=Open Systems for Better Business: Something Ventured, Something Gained|first=Ann|last=Senn|publisher=Van Nostrand Reinhold|year=1995|isbn=978-0-442-01911-2}}</ref> [[William Safire]] wrote in his 1993 book ''Quoth the Maven'' that disinformation was used by the KGB predecessor to indicate: "manipulation of a nation's intelligence system through the injection of credible, but misleading data".<ref name=annsenn /> From this point on, disinformation became a tactic used in the Soviet political warfare called [[active measures]].<ref name=nicholasjohncull>{{citation|title=Propaganda and Mass Persuasion: A Historical Encyclopedia, 1500 to the Present|author1=Nicholas John Cull |author2=David Holbrook Culbert |author3=David Welch |page=104|chapter=Disinformation|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|year=2003|isbn=9781610690713}}</ref><ref name=manningromerstein /> Active measures were a crucial part of Soviet intelligence strategy involving [[forgery as covert operation]], [[subversion]], and [[media manipulation]].<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/06/opinion/for-putin-disinformation-is-power.html|accessdate=9 December 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=5 August 2016|title=For Putin, Disinformation Is Power|first=Arkady|last=Ostrovsky}}</ref> The 2003 encyclopedia ''Propaganda and Mass Persuasion'' states that ''disinformation'' came from ''dezinformatsia'', a term used by the Russian black propaganda unit known as Service A which referred to active measures.<ref name=nicholasjohncull /> The term was used in 1939, related to a "German Disinformation Service".<ref name=fowlers>{{citation|title=Fowler's Dictionary of Modern English Usage|author1=Henry Watson Fowler |author2=Jeremy Butterfield|page=223|year=2015|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-966135-0}}</ref><ref name=merriam>{{citation|pages=143–144|title=The Merriam-Webster New Book of Word Histories|publisher=Merriam-Webster, Inc|location=Springfield, Massachusetts|year=1991|isbn=978-0-87779-603-9|chapter=disinformation}}</ref> The 1991 edition of ''The Merriam-Webster New Book of Word Histories'' defines ''disinformation'' as a probable translation of the Russian ''dezinformatsiya''.<ref name=merriam /> This dictionary notes that it was possible the English version of the word and the Russian language version developed independently in parallel to each other—out of ongoing frustration related to the spread of propaganda before [[World War II|World War II]].<ref name=merriam />
[[File:Ion Mihai Pacepa 1975cr.jpg|thumb|Former [[Siguranța|Romanian secret police]] senior official [[Ion Mihai Pacepa]] exposed disinformation history in his book ''[[Disinformation (book)|Disinformation]]'' (2013).<ref name=adamtaylor />]] [[Ion Mihai Pacepa]], former senior official from the [[Siguranța|Romanian secret police]], said the word was coined by [[Joseph Stalin]] and used during World War II.<ref name=adamtaylor /><ref name=pacepa>{{citation|title=Disinformation: Former Spy Chief Reveals Secret Strategies for Undermining Freedom, Attacking Religion, and Promoting Terrorism|year=2013|author= [[Ion Mihai Pacepa]] and [[Ronald J. Rychlak]]|isbn=978-1-936488-60-5|publisher=WND Books|pages=4–6, 34–39, 75|title-link=Disinformation (book)}}</ref> The [[Stalinist]] government then utilized disinformation tactics in both World War II and the Cold War.<ref>{{citation|title=Investigating Information-based Crimes|first=Ronald L. |last=Mendell|page=45|year=2013|isbn=978-0-398-08871-2|publisher=Charles C Thomas Publisher Ltd|chapter=Disinformation}}</ref> Soviet intelligence used the term ''maskirovka'' ([[Russian military deception]]) to refer to a combination of tactics including disinformation, simulation, camouflage, and concealment.<ref name=rothsteinwhaley>{{citation|title=The Art and Science of Military Deception|author1=Hy Rothstein |author2=Barton Whaley|pages=189–192|series=Artech House Intelligence and Information Operations|publisher=Artech House Publishers |year=2013|isbn=978-1-60807-551-5|chapter=Catching NATO Unawares: Soviet Army Surprise and Deception Techniques}}</ref> Pacepa and [[Ronald J. Rychlak]] authored a book titled ''[[Disinformation (book)|Disinformation]]'', in which Pacepa wrote that Stalin gave the tactic a French-sounding title in order to put forth the ruse that it was actually a technique used by the [[Western world]].<ref name=pacepa /> Pacepa recounted reading Soviet instruction manuals while working as an intelligence officer, that characterized disinformation as a strategy utilized by the [[Russian government]] that had early origins in [[Russian history]].<ref name=adamtaylor /><ref name=pacepa /> Pacepa recalled that the Soviet manuals said the origins of disinformation stemmed from phony towns constructed by [[Grigory Potyomkin]] in [[Crimea]] to wow [[Catherine the Great]] during her 1783 journey to the region—subsequently referred to as [[Potemkin village]]s.<ref name=adamtaylor /><ref name=pacepa />
In their book ''Propaganda and Persuasion'', authors Garth Jowett and Victoria O'Donnell characterized ''disinformation'' as a [[cognate]] from ''dezinformatsia'', and was developed from the same name given to a KGB [[black propaganda]] department.<ref name=jowett>{{citation|author1=Garth Jowett |author2=Victoria O'Donnell|title=Propaganda and Persuasion|pages=21–23|publisher=Sage Publications|isbn=978-1-4129-0898-6|year=2005|chapter=What Is Propaganda, and How Does It Differ From Persuasion?|quote=In fact, the word disinformation is a cognate for the Russian dezinformatsia, taken from the name of a division of the KGB devoted to black propaganda.}}</ref> The black propaganda division was reported to have formed in 1955 and was referred to as the Dezinformatsiya agency.<ref name=merriam /> Former [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA) director [[William Colby]] explained how the Dezinformatsiya agency operated, saying that it would place a false article in a left-leaning newspaper.<ref name=merriam /> The fraudulent tale would make its way to a Communist periodical, before eventually being published by a Soviet newspaper, which would say its sources were undisclosed individuals.<ref name=merriam /> By this process a falsehood was globally proliferated as a legitimate piece of reporting.<ref name=merriam />
According to ''Oxford Dictionaries'' the English word ''disinformation'', as translated from the Russian ''disinformatsiya'', began to see use in the 1950s.<ref name=oxfordweb>{{citation|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/disinformation|accessdate=9 December 2016|date=2016|chapter=disinformation|title=English Oxford Living Dictionaries|publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref> The term ''disinformation'' began to see wider use as a form of Soviet [[tradecraft]], defined in the 1952 official ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' as "the dissemination (in the press, radio, etc.) of false information with the intention to deceive public opinion."<ref name=bittman1985 /><ref name=adamtaylor /> During the most-active period of the [[Cold War]], from 1945 to 1989, the tactic was used by multiple intelligence agencies including the Soviet KGB, British [[Secret Intelligence Service]], and the American CIA.<ref name=fowlers /> The word ''disinformation'' saw increased usage in the 1960s and wider purveyance by the 1980s.<ref name=adamtaylor>{{citation|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/11/26/before-fake-news-there-was-soviet-disinformation|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=26 November 2016|accessdate=3 December 2016|title=Before 'fake news,' there was Soviet 'disinformation'|first=Adam|last=Taylor}}</ref> Former Soviet bloc intelligence officer [[Ladislav Bittman]], the first disinformation practitioner to publicly defect to the West, described the official definition as different from the practice: "The interpretation is slightly distorted because public opinion is only one of the potential targets. Many disinformation games are designed only to manipulate the decision-making elite, and receive no publicity."<ref name=bittman1985 /> Bittman was deputy chief of the Disinformation Department of the [[Czechoslovak Intelligence Service]], and testified before the [[United States Congress]] on his knowledge of disinformation in 1980.<ref name=nicholasjohncull />
Disinformation may include distribution of [[Forgery|forged]] [[document]]s, manuscripts, and photographs, or spreading dangerous [[rumour]]s and [[Fabrication (science)|fabricated]] [[intelligence]]. A major disinformation effort in 1964, [[Operation Neptune (espionage)|Operation Neptune]], was designed by the [[Czechoslavakia|Czechoslovak]] secret service, the [[StB]], to defame West European politicians as former [[Nazi collaborators]].<ref name=bittman1972>{{citation|first=Ladislav|last= Bittman|authorlink=Lawrence Martin-Bittman|title=The Deception Game: Czechoslovak Intelligence in Soviet Political Warfare|publisher=Syracuse University Research Corporation|year=1972|isbn=978-0-8156-8078-9|pages=39–78}}</ref>
==Defections reveal covert operations== [[File:E Primakov 03.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Director of SVR|Chief of Russian foreign intelligence]] [[Yevgeny Primakov]] confirmed in 1992 that [[Operation INFEKTION]] was a disinformation campaign to make the world believe the [[United States|U.S.]] invented [[AIDS]].<ref name=adamtaylor /><ref name=usstate />]] The extent of Soviet disinformation [[covert operation]] campaigns, came to light through the [[defection]]s of KGB officers and officers of allied Soviet bloc services from the late 1960s through the 1980s.<ref name=holland2012 /><ref name=davidmartin /> Disorder during the [[fall of the Soviet Union]] revealed archival and other documentary information to confirm what the defectors had revealed.<ref name=holland2012>{{citation|title=The Propagation and Power of Communist Security Services Dezinformatsiya|journal=[[International Journal of Intelligence and CounterIntelligence]]|volume=19|issue=1|year=2006|first=Max|last=Holland|doi=10.1080/08850600500332342|pages=1–31}} </ref> [[Stanislav Levchenko]] and Ilya Dzerkvilov defected from the Soviet Union and by 1990 each had written books recounting their work in the KGB on disinformation operations.<ref name=davidmartin />
In 1961, a pamphlet was published in the United Kingdom titled: ''A Study of a Master Spy (Allen Dulles)'', which was highly critical of then-[[Director of Central Intelligence]] [[Allen Dulles]].<ref name=jmichaelwaller /> The purported authors were given as [[Independent Labour Party]] [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Member of Parliament]] [[Bob Edwards (politician)|Bob Edwards]] and reporter Kenneth Dunne—when in actual fact the author was senior disinformation officer KGB Colonel Vassily Sitnikov.<ref name=jmichaelwaller>{{citation|title=Strategic Influence: Public Diplomacy, Counterpropaganda, and Political Warfare|first=J. Michael|last=Waller|pages=159–161|publisher=Institute of World Politics Press|isbn=978-0-9792236-4-8|year=2009}}</ref>
An example of successful Soviet disinformation was the publication in 1968 of ''[[Who's Who in the CIA]]'' which was quoted as authoritative in the West until the early 1990s.<ref name=usia1992>{{citation|author=[[United States Information Agency]]|url=http://intellit.muskingum.edu/russia_folder/pcw_era/sect_09b.htm|chapter=Crude, Anti-American Disinformation: 'Geheim' and 'Top Secret' Magazines: Purveyors of Crude, Defamatory Disinformation|title=Soviet Active Measures in the 'Post-Cold War' Era 1988-1991 - A Report Prepared at the Request of the United States House of Representatives Committee on Appropriations by the United States Information Agency|year=1992|location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=United States Government Printing Office}} </ref>
According to senior [[Foreign Intelligence Service (Russia)|SVR]] officer [[Sergei Tretyakov (intelligence officer)|Sergei Tretyakov]], the KGB was responsible for creating the entire [[nuclear winter]] story to stop the deployment of [[Pershing II]] missiles.<ref name="Comrade J">{{citation|first=Pete |last=Earley|title=Comrade J: The Untold Secrets of Russia's Master Spy in America After the End of the Cold War|publisher=Penguin Books|year=2007|isbn=978-0-399-15439-3|pages=167–177}}</ref> Tretyakov says that from 1979 the KGB wanted to prevent the United States from deploying the missiles in Western Europe and that, directed by [[Yuri Andropov]], they distributed disinformation, based on a faked "doomsday report" by the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|Soviet Academy of Sciences]] about the effect of nuclear war on climate, to peace groups, the environmental movement and the journal [[AMBIO|''AMBIO: A Journal of the Human Environment'']].<ref name="Comrade J" />
[[File:Deception, Disinformation, and Strategic Communications.pdf|thumb|left|''Deception, Disinformation, and Strategic Communications'', cover illustrating propaganda from [[Operation INFEKTION]]]] During the 1970s, the U.S. intelligence apparatus paid little attention to try to counter Soviet disinformation campaigns.<ref name=jmichaelwaller /> This posture changed in September 1980 during the [[Carter Administration]], when the [[White House]] was subjected to a propaganda operation by Soviet intelligence regarding international relations between the U.S. and South Africa.<ref name=jmichaelwaller /> On 17 September 1980, White House Press Secretary [[Jody Powell]] acknowledged a falsified ''Presidential Review Memorandum on Africa'' reportedly stated the U.S. endorsed the [[apartheid]] government in South Africa and was actively committed to discrimination against African Americans.<ref name=jmichaelwaller /> Prior to this revelation by Powell, an advance copy of the 18 September 1980 issue of San Francisco-based publication the ''Sun Reporter'' was disseminated, which carried the fake claims.<ref name=jmichaelwaller /> ''Sun Reporter'' was published by [[Carlton Benjamin Goodlett]], Presidential Committee member of the Soviet [[front group]] the [[World Peace Council]].<ref name=jmichaelwaller /> U.S. President [[Jimmy Carter]] was appalled at these lies and subsequently the Carter Administration displayed increased interest in CIA efforts to counter Soviet disinformation.<ref name=jmichaelwaller />
In 1982, the CIA issued a report on active measures used by Soviet intelligence.<ref name=josephgoulden /> The report documented numerous instances of disinformation campaigns against the U.S., including planting a notion that the U.S. had organized the 1979 [[Grand Mosque seizure]], and forgery of documents purporting to show the U.S. would utilize [[nuclear bomb]]s on its [[NATO]] allies.<ref name=josephgoulden>{{citation|title=The Dictionary of Espionage: Spyspeak into English|first=Joseph|last=Goulden|page=64|chapter=Disinformation (''dezinformatsiya'')|series=Dover Military History, Weapons, Armor|year=2012|publisher=Dover Publications|isbn=978-0-486-48348-1}}</ref>
[[Operation INFEKTION]] was an elaborate disinformation campaign which began in 1985, to influence world opinion to believe that the United States had invented [[AIDS]].<ref name=adamtaylor /><ref name=usstate /> This included the allegation that the purpose was the creation of an 'ethnic bomb' to destroy non-whites.<ref name=usstate>{{citation|author=[[United States Department of State]]|title=Soviet Influence Activities: A Report on Active Measures and Propaganda, 1986–87|location=Washington D.C.|publisher=Bureau of Public Affairs|year=1987|pages=34–35, 39, 42}}</ref> In 1992, the [[Director of SVR|head of Russian foreign intelligence]], [[Yevgeny Primakov]], admitted the existence of the Operation INFEKTION disinformation campaign.<ref name=adamtaylor /><ref name=usstate />
In 1985, [[Aldrich Ames]] gave the KGB a significant amount of information on CIA agents, and the Soviet government swiftly moved to arrest these individuals.<ref name=lochkjohnson>{{citation|title=The Oxford Handbook of National Security Intelligence|editor1-first=Loch K.|editor1-last=Johnson|pages=548–550|chapter=Counterintelligence as Disinformation Operations|isbn=978-0-19-992947-4|year=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|series=Oxford Handbooks}}</ref> Soviet intelligence feared this rapid action would alert the CIA that Ames was a spy.<ref name=lochkjohnson /> In order to reduce the chances the CIA would discover Ames's duplicity, the KGB manufactured disinformation as to the reasoning behind the arrests of U.S. intelligence agents.<ref name=lochkjohnson /> During summer 1985, a KGB officer who was a [[double agent]] working for the CIA on a mission in Africa traveled to a [[dead drop]] in Moscow on his way home but never reported in.<ref name=lochkjohnson /> The CIA heard from a European KGB source that their agent was arrested.<ref name=lochkjohnson /> Simultaneously the FBI and CIA learned from a second KGB source of their agent's arrest.<ref name=lochkjohnson /> Only after Ames had been outed as a spy for the KGB did it become apparent that the KGB had known all along that both of these agents were double agents for the U.S. government, and had played them as pawns to send disinformation to the CIA in order to protect Ames.<ref name=lochkjohnson />
==Post Soviet-era Russian disinformation== In the post-Soviet era, disinformation evolved to become a key tactic in the [[military doctrine of Russia]].<ref name=powerfulrussian>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/29/world/europe/russia-sweden-disinformation.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=9 December 2016|title=A Powerful Russian Weapon: The Spread of False Stories|date=28 August 2016|first=Neil|last=MacFarquharaug|page=A1}}</ref>
The [[European Union]] and [[NATO]] saw Russian disinformation in the early 21st century as such a problem that they both set up special units to analyze and debunk fabricated falsehoods.<ref name=powerfulrussian /> NATO founded a modest facility in Latvia to respond to disinformation<ref>{{citation|accessdate=9 December 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]|title=The danger of Russian disinformation|date=6 May 2016|author1=Anne Applebaum |author2=Edward Lucas|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/the-danger-of-russian-disinformation/2016/05/06/b31d9718-12d5-11e6-8967-7ac733c56f12_story.html}}</ref> and, following agreement by heads of state and governments in March 2015 the EU created the [[European External Action Service]] East Stratcom Task Force, which publishes weekly reports in its website "EU vs Disinfo".<ref name=euvsd>{{cite web|url=https://euvsdisinfo.eu/|title=EU vs Disinfo|website=EU vs Disinfo|publisher=European External Action Service East Stratcom Task Force|accessdate=3 December 2017}}</ref> The website and its partners identified and debunked over 3,500 pro-Kremlin disinformation cases between September 2015 and November 2017.<ref name=euvsd />
Methods used by Russia during this period included its Kremlin-controlled mouthpieces: news agency ''[[Sputnik News]]'' and television outlet ''[[Russia Today]]'' (RT).<ref name=powerfulrussian /> When explaining the 2016 annual report of the [[Swedish Security Service]] on disinformation, representative Wilhelm Unge stated: "We mean everything from Internet trolls to propaganda and misinformation spread by media companies like RT and Sputnik."<ref name=powerfulrussian />
Later in the 21st century, as social media gained prominence, Russia began to use popular platforms such as Facebook and Twitter to spread disinformation. Facebook believes that as many as 126 million users have seen content from Russian disinformation campaigns on its platform. Twitter has said that it has found 36,000 Russian bots spreading tweets related to the 2016 American election.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/11/14/564013066/russia-using-disinformation-to-sow-discord-in-west-britains-prime-minister-says|title=Russia Using Disinformation To 'Sow Discord In West,' Britain's Prime Minister Says|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-02-20|language=en}}</ref> Elsewhere, Russia has used social media to destabilize former soviet states such as Ukraine and other western nations such as France and Spain.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/01/06/508032496/how-russias-disinformation-campaign-could-extend-its-tentacles|title=How Russia's Disinformation Campaign Could Extend Its Tentacles|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-02-20|language=en}}</ref>
==English language spread== [[File:How Disinformation Can Be Spread.jpg|thumb|250px|How Disinformation Can Be Spread, explanation by [[United States Department of Defense|U.S. Defense Department]] (2001)]] The [[United States Intelligence Community]] appropriated usage of the term ''disinformation'' in the 1950s from the Russian ''dezinformatsiya'', and began to utilize similar strategies<ref name=manningromerstein /><ref>{{citation|page=118|title=Right Words|first=Stephen |last=Murray-Smith|publisher=Viking|year=1989|isbn=978-0-670-82825-8}}</ref> during the Cold War and in conflict with other nations.<ref name=adamtaylor /> ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported in 2000 that during the CIA's effort to substitute [[Mohammed Reza Pahlavi]] for then-[[Prime Minister of Iran]] [[Mohammad Mossadegh]], the CIA placed fictitious stories in the local newspaper.<ref name=adamtaylor /> [[Reuters]] documented how, subsequent to the 1979 Soviet Union invasion of Afghanistan during the [[Soviet–Afghan War]], the CIA put false articles in newspapers of Islamic-majority countries, inaccurately stating that Soviet embassies had "invasion day celebrations".<ref name=adamtaylor /> Reuters noted a former U.S. intelligence officer said they would attempt to gain the confidence of reporters and use them as [[secret agent]]s, to impact a nation's politics by way of their local media.<ref name=adamtaylor />
In October 1986, the term gained increased currency in the U.S. when it was revealed that two months previously, the [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|Reagan Administration]] had engaged in a disinformation campaign against then-leader of [[Libya]], [[Muammar Gaddafi]].<ref name=biagi>{{citation|title=Media/Impact: An Introduction to Mass Media|first=Shirley|last=Biagi|page=328|chapter=Disinformation|year=2014|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-1-133-31138-6}}</ref> [[White House]] representative [[Larry Speakes]] said reports of a planned attack on Libya as first broken by ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' on August 25, 1986 were "authoritative", and other newspapers including ''[[The Washington Post]]'' then wrote articles saying this was factual.<ref name=biagi /> [[United States Department of State]] representative [[Bernard Kalb]] resigned from his position in protest over the disinformation campaign, and said: "Faith in the word of America is the pulse beat of our democracy."<ref name=biagi />
The executive branch of the Reagan Administration kept watch on disinformation campaigns through three yearly publications by the Department of State: ''Active Measures: A Report on the Substance and Process of Anti-U.S. Disinformation and Propaganda Campaigns'' (1986); ''Report on Active Measures and Propaganda, 1986–87'' (1987); and ''Report on Active Measures and Propaganda, 1987–88'' (1989).<ref name=manningromerstein />
''Disinformation'' first made an appearance in dictionaries in 1985, specifically ''Webster's New College Dictionary'' and the ''American Heritage Dictionary'' in 1985.<ref name= bittman1988>{{citation|title=The New Image-Makers: Soviet Propaganda & Disinformation Today|first=Ladislav|last=Bittman|authorlink=Lawrence Martin-Bittman|year=1988|pages=7, 24|isbn=978-0-08-034939-8|publisher=Brassey's Inc}}</ref> In 1986, the term ''disinformation'' was not defined in ''Webster's New World Thesaurus'' or ''New Encyclopædia Britannica''.<ref name=pacepa /> After the Soviet term became widely known in the 1980s, native speakers of English broadened the term as "any government communication (either overt or covert) containing intentionally false and misleading material, often combined selectively with true information, which seeks to mislead and [[Psychological manipulation|manipulate]] either elites or a mass audience."<ref name=shultzgodson>{{citation|first1=Richard H.|last1= Shultz |first2=Roy|last2= Godson|author1-link=Richard H. Shultz|author2-link=Roy Godson|title=Dezinformatsia: Active Measures in Soviet Strategy|publisher=Pergamon-Brassey's|year=1984|isbn=978-0-08-031573-7|pages=37–38|title-link= Dezinformatsia (book) }}</ref>
By 1990, use of the term ''disinformation'' had fully established itself in the English language within the lexicon of politics.<ref name=davidmartin>{{citation|title=The Web of Disinformation: Churchill's Yugoslav Blunder|first=David|last=Martin|page=xx|publisher=Harcourt Brace Jovanovich|year=1990|isbn=978-0-15-180704-8}}</ref> By 2001, the term ''disinformation'' had come to be known as simply a more civil phrase for saying someone was spouting [[lie]]s.<ref name=heinemann>{{citation|page=124|title=Developing Media Skills|first=Geoff |last=Barton |publisher=Heinemann|isbn=978-0-435-10960-8|year=2001}}</ref> Stanley B. Cunningham wrote in his 2002 book ''The Idea of Propaganda'' that ''disinformation'' had become pervasively utilized as a synonym for [[propaganda]].<ref name=cunningham>{{citation|title=The Idea of Propaganda: A Reconstruction|first=Stanley B. |last=Cunningham|pages=67–68, 110|chapter=Disinformation (Russian: ''dezinformatsiya'')|year=2002|isbn=978-0-275-97445-9|publisher=Praeger}}</ref>
==Analysis== The authors of a 2006 book about [[psychopathy in the workplace]], ''[[Snakes in Suits]]'' describe a five-phase model of how a typical workplace [[psychopath]] climbs to and maintains [[Power (social and political)|power]]. In phase three, manipulation, the psychopath will create a scenario of "[[Cognitive distortion|psychopathic fiction]]"—where positive information about themselves and negative disinformation about others will be created, casting others in roles as a part of a network of [[Flying monkeys (psychology)|pawns or patrons]] to be utilized and [[Operant conditioning|groomed]] into accepting the psychopath's agenda.<ref name=Snakes>{{citation|first1=Paul |last=Babiak |first2= Robert D. |last2=Hare|title=Snakes in Suits: When Psychopaths Go to Work|publisher=HarperCollins|year=2007|page=240|isbn=978-0061147890|title-link=Snakes in Suits: When Psychopaths Go to Work }}</ref>
In a contribution to the 2014 book ''Military Ethics and Emerging Technologies'', writers David Danks and Joseph H. Danks discuss the ethical implications in using disinformation as a tactic during [[information warfare]].<ref name=daviddanks>{{citation|title=Military Ethics and Emerging Technologies|editor1=Timothy J. Demy|editor2=George R. Lucas Jr.|editor3=Bradley J. Strawser|pages=223–224|first1=David|last1=Danks|first2=Joseph H.|last2=Danks|publisher=Routledge|chapter=The Moral Responsibility of Automated Responses During Cyberwarfare|year=2014|isbn=978-0-415-73710-4}}</ref> They note there has been a significant degree of philosophical debate over the issue as related to the [[ethics of war]] and use of the technique.<ref name=daviddanks /> The writers describe a position whereby use of disinformation is occasionally allowed, but not in all situations.<ref name=daviddanks /> Typically the ethical test to consider is whether the disinformation was performed out of a motivation of [[good faith]] and acceptable according to the [[rules of war]].<ref name=daviddanks /> By this test, the tactic during World War II of putting fake inflatable tanks in visible locations on the [[Pacific Islands]] in order to falsely present the impression that there were larger military forces present would be considered as ethically permissible.<ref name=daviddanks /> Conversely, disguising a munitions plant as a healthcare facility in order to avoid attack would be outside the bounds of acceptable use of disinformation during war.<ref name=daviddanks />
[[Pope Francis]] criticized disinformation in a 2016 interview, after being made the subject of a [[fake news website]]—during the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 U.S. election]] cycle he was falsely said to support [[Donald Trump]].<ref name=popewarnsnyt>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/12/07/world/europe/ap-eu-rel-vatican-fake-news.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=7 December 2016|accessdate=7 December 2016|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Pope Warns About Fake News-From Experience}}</ref><ref name=alyssanewcomb>{{citation|work=[[NBC News]]|accessdate=16 November 2016|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/facebook-google-crack-down-fake-news-advertising-n684101|title=Facebook, Google Crack Down on Fake News Advertising|author=Alyssa Newcomb|publisher=NBC News|date=15 November 2016}}</ref><ref name=didthepope>{{citation|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2016/10/did-the-pope-endorse-trump/|accessdate=7 December 2016|work=[[FactCheck.org]]|title=Did the Pope Endorse Trump?|first=Sydney|last= Schaede|date=24 October 2016}}</ref> He said the worst thing the news media could do was spread disinformation, that it was a [[sin]],<ref name=popewarnsreuters>{{citation|work=[[Reuters]]|date=7 December 2016|accessdate=7 December 2016|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-pope-media-idUSKBN13W1TU|title=Pope warns media over 'sin' of spreading fake news, smearing politicians|first=Philip|last= Pullella}}</ref><ref name=harrietsherwood>{{citation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/07/pope-compares-fake-news-consumption-to-eating-faeces-coprophilia|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=7 December 2016|accessdate=7 December 2016|title=Pope Francis compares fake news consumption to eating faeces}}</ref> comparing those who spread disinformation to individuals who engage in [[coprophilia]].<ref December 2016|date=7 December 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]|title=Pope Francis compares media that spread fake news to people who are excited by feces|first=Julie|last= Zauzmer}}</ref><ref {{expert-subject|Physics|ex2=Philosophy|date=February 2009}}
'''Endophysics''' literally means “[[physics]] from within”. It is the study of how the observations are affected and limited by the observer being within the universe. This is in contrast with the common '''exophysics''' assumption of a system observed from the “outside”. The term ''endophysics'' has been coined by [[David Finkelstein]] in a letter to the founder of the field [[Otto E. Rössler]].
==See also== * [[physics]] * [[internal measurement]] (This notion is very similar to endophysics.)
==References== {{reflist}} * R. J. Boskovich, De spacio et tempore, ut a nobis cognoscuntur, partial English translation in: J. M. Child (Ed.), A Theory of Natural Philosophy, Open Court (1922) and MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, 1966, pp. 203–205. * T. Toffoli, The role of the observer in uniform systems, in: [[G. J. Klir]] (Ed.), Applied General Systems Research, Recent Developments and Trends, Plenum Press, New York, London, 1978, pp. 395–400. * K. Svozil, Connections between deviations from Lorentz transformation and relativistic energy-momentum relation, Europhysics Letters 2 (1986) 83–85. * O. E. Rössler, Endophysics, in: J. L. Casti, A. Karlquist (Eds.), Real Brains, Artificial Minds, North-Holland, New York, 1987, p. 25. * O. E. Rössler, Endophysics. Die Welt des inneren Beobachters, Merwe Verlag, Berlin, 1992, with a foreword by Peter Weibel. * K. Svozil, Extrinsic-intrinsic concept and complementarity, in: H. Atmanspacker, G. J. Dalenoort (Eds.), Inside versus Outside, Springer-Verlag, Heidelberg, 1994, pp. 273–288.
==External links== * Karl Svozil (2005). [https://arxiv.org/abs/physics/0305048 Computational universes]. {{doi|10.1016/j.chaos.2004.11.055}} * Interview with O. E. Rössler (in German) [http://www.telepolis.de/r4/artikel/5/5004/1.html Vom Chaos, der Virtuellen Realität und der Endophysik]

The '''Evangelical Philosophical Society''' (EPS) is an organization devoted to the study of [[ethics]], [[theology]], and [[religion]] from an [[evangelicalism|evangelical]] perspective. Membership is open to professional [[scholar]]s and associate membership is available to laypersons and students. Since 2006, [[Paul Copan]] has been the president of the organization.<ref>[http://www.paulcopan.com/cv/ Paul Copan's Curriculum Vitae], January 31, 2012</ref>
==''Philosophia Christi''== {{main|Philosophia Christi}} '''''Philosophia Christi''''' is a [[peer-review]]ed [[academic journal]] published twice a year by the Evangelical Philosophical Society with the support of [[Biola University]] as a vehicle for the scholarly discussion of philosophy and philosophical issues in the fields of [[apologetics]], [[ethics]], [[theology]], and [[religion]].<ref>[http://www.epsociety.org/philchristi/ About Philosophia Christi]</ref>
== History ==
The Evangelical Philosophical Society is related to the [[Evangelical Theological Society]]. EPS was founded in 1977–78 with 32 charter members.
The first presidents were:
* 1977 – [[Norman Geisler]] * 1978 – Gordon Lewis * 1979 – [[Paul Feinberg]] * 1980 – [[John Jefferson Davis]] * 1981 – [[Gary Habermas]] * 1982 – [[Stephen Clinton]] * 1983 – [[Win Corduan]] * 1984 – [[Terry Miethe]] * 1985 – [[William Luck]] * 1986 – [[John Feinberg]] * 1987 – [[Stephen Spenser]] * 1988 – [[Stanley Obbits]] * 1989 – [[Russell Bush]]
== See also == * [[Society of Christian Philosophers]] * [[Evangelical Theological Society]]
==References== {{Reflist|refs=
}}
