{{Infobox scholar |name = Mark Slonim |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Mark Lvovich Slonim |other_names = Marc Slonim, Marco Slonim |birth_date = March 23, 1894 |birth_place = [[Odessa]], [[Russian Empire]] |death_date = {{death year and age|1976|1894}} |death_place = [[Beaulieu-sur-Mer]], [[Alpes-Maritimes]], France |era = 20th century |region = [[Eastern Europe]] |school_tradition = {{hlist|[[Narodnik]]|[[Libertarian socialism]]|[[Aestheticism]]|[[Russian formalism|Formalism]]}} |main_interests = [[Political theory]], [[Russian studies]], [[Russian literature]], [[Comparative literature]] |major_works = |influences = [[Nikolay Chernyshevsky]], [[Alexander Herzen]], [[Eugène-Melchior de Vogüé]] |influenced = |workplaces = {{unbulleted list |Russian Free University |[[Sarah Lawrence College]] |Institute for Slavic Philology ([[Sapienza University of Rome|La Sapienza University]]) }} }} '''Mark Lvovich Slonim''' ({{lang-ru|Марк Льво́вич Сло́ним}}, also known as '''Marc Slonim''' and '''Marco Slonim'''; March 23, 1894<ref name="mlsrussi">{{it icon}} Giuseppina Giuliano, [http://www.russinitalia.it/dettaglio.php?id=387 "Mark L'vovič Slonim"], [http://www.russinitalia.it/ ''Russi in Italia'' database] entry; retrieved October 15, 2015</ref> – 1976) was a Russian politician, literary critic, scholar and translator. He was a lifelong member of the [[Socialist Revolutionary Party]], and, in 1917, served as its deputy for [[Bessarabia]] in the [[Russian Constituent Assembly]]. He joined the [[Committee of Members of the Constituent Assembly|Samara Government]] during the early phases of the [[Russian Civil War|Civil War]], opposing both the [[Bolsheviks]] and the conservative elements of the [[White movement]]. Assigned to his party's Foreign Delegation, Slonim lobbied unsuccessfully for the return of Bessarabia to Russia during the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]]. After a short stay in [[Tuscany]], he settled in [[First Czechoslovak Republic|Czechoslovakia]] in 1922, an editor of ''Volya Rossii'' review.
Slonim, who was also an Italian-trained literary scholar, became ''Volya Rossii''{{'}}s literary theorist and columnist. From that vantage point, he gave encouraged the liberal-progressive and [[Modernist literature|modernist]] side of the [[White émigré]] intellectuals. Slonim argued, against conservatives such as [[Zinaida Gippius]], that the exiles needed to appreciate changes occurring in the [[Soviet Union]] and became one of the first popularizers of Soviet writers in the West. He was also one of the main backers (and an intimate friend) of poet [[Marina Tsvetaeva]].
In 1928, convinced that [[Russian literature]] in exile was in fact dead, Slonim moved to Paris and, as an anti-fascist, opened up to [[Soviet socialist patriotism|Soviet patriotism]]. His 1930s contacts with the [[Union for repatriation of Russians abroad|Union for Repatriation]] were particularly controversial. He escaped World War II and arrived to the United States aboard the [[SS Navemar|SS ''Navemar'']], spending the 1940s and '50s as a teacher at [[Sarah Lawrence College]]. He continued to publish tracts and textbooks on Russian literary topics, familiarizing the American public with the major trends of Soviet poetry and fiction. He spent his final years in [[Geneva]], where he translated [[Andrei Bely]]'s ''Silver Dove'' and worked sporadically on his memoirs.
==Biography==
===Early activities=== Slonim was born in the [[Russian Empire]]'s port city of [[Odessa]] (now in [[Ukraine]]),<ref name="mlsrussi"/><ref>[http://www2.jewishgen.org/Ukraine/RES_MNI_Det.asp?id=46305 Ukraine Master Index of Names], birth record at the office of the Odessa city rabbi, [[JewishGen]]</ref> although some sources have [[Novgorod-Severskiy]], [[Chernihiv Governorate]].<ref name="Aucouturier 1977 p. 411">Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), p. 411; Aucouturier (1999), p. 379</ref> His parents were upper-middle-class [[History of the Jews in Russia|Russian Jewish]] intellectuals; Slonim's uncle was the literary critic [[Yuly Aykhenvald]].<ref name="Aucouturier 1977 p. 411"/> The future critic was also a distant relative of Yevsey Lazarevich Slonim, whose daughter, [[Véra Nabokov|Vera Yevseyevna]], became the wife of novelist [[Vladimir Nabokov]].<ref name="boyd85">[[Brian Boyd]], ''Vladimir Nabokov: The American Years'', p. 85. Princeton: [[Princeton University Press]], 1991. {{ISBN|0-691-06797-X}}</ref> According to Russologist Michel Aucouturier, Slonim's memoirs show him as an erudite and an adept of [[aestheticism]], whose "socialist sympathies" were only cemented by the [[Russian Revolution]].<ref name="Aucouturier p. 411">Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), p. 411</ref> While completing his secondary studies at a classical gymnasium in Odessa, Slonim came into contact with the Socialist Revolutionaries (or "Esers"), and, like his older brother Vladimir before him, became their follower.<ref>Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), pp. 411, 413–415</ref> Their radicalism pitied them against their father, who supported the moderate-liberal [[Constitutional Democratic Party|Kadet Party]].<ref>Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), p. 413</ref>
Slonim, who regarded himself as a [[libertarian socialist]] rather than a [[Marxism|Marxist]], worked on establishing "self-instruction circles", circulating banned literature among students, artisans and workers, and traveled to Europe to meet with [[Osip Minor]].<ref>Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), pp. 414–417</ref> As he recalled in the 1960s, the Eser leadership was "appalled to discover than in Odessa and the nearby region most of the work was being done by boys and girls of 16 or 17."<ref>Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), p. 417</ref> According to later sources, he was brought to the attention of the [[Okhrana]] and left Russia surreptitiously.<ref name="mlsrussi"/> From 1911, he studied philosophy and literature at the [[University of Florence]],<ref name="csimigr343">{{it icon}} Claudia Scandura, [http://www.europaorientalis.it/uploads/files/1995%20n.2/1995%20n.%202.16.pdf "L'Emigrazione russa in Italia: 1918–1919"], in ''Europa Orientalis'', Vol. 14, Issue 2, 1995, p. 343</ref> where he took his [[Ph.D.]]<ref name="krfreedom">Katharine Reece, [https://www.sarahlawrence.edu/magazine/then-now/features/recovering-marc.html "Freedom of Thought, Freedom to Learn: Recovering Marc Slonim"], in ''Sarah Lawrence Magazine'', Spring 2015</ref> In 1914, he published in Italy a translation of [[Ivan Turgenev]]'s poetry cicle, ''Senility''.<ref name="mlsrussi"/> By 1918, Slonim was also a graduate of [[Saint Petersburg State University|Saint Petersburg Imperial University]].<ref name="mlsrussi"/><ref>White, p. 25</ref>
Upon the start of World War I, Slonim followed the "defensist" line of the Eser mainstream, supporting Russia's commitment to the [[Allies of World War I|Allies]], and served in the [[Imperial Russian Army|Imperial Army]]. The [[February Revolution]] caught him on the [[Romania in World War I|Romanian Front]],<ref>Constantin ''et al.'' (2011), pp. 394, 404; White, p. 25</ref> but he soon returned to [[Petrograd]], where (Aucouturier writes) "his talents as a propagandist and an orator soon made him one of his party's celebrities".<ref name="Aucouturier p. 411"/> Slonim supported the [[Russian Provisional Government]] and its "defensist" policies against the [[Left Socialist Revolutionaries|Left Esers]], with public disputations against [[Vladimir Karelin]] and [[Maria Spiridonova]].<ref>Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), pp. 424–428. See also White, p. 25</ref> According to Slonim, he was one of the youths left in charge of party work: the more senior Esers were either in government or consumed by work in the [[Petrograd Soviet|Soviet of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies]].<ref>Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), pp. 423–424</ref>
===Constituent Assembly and Paris Conference=== In his memoirs, Slonim claims to have foreseen the danger posed by the reorganized [[Bolsheviks]], having heard their leader, [[Vladimir Lenin]], speak. He contrasts Bolshevik unity with the Esers' indecisiveness and factionalism.<ref>Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), pp. 429–434</ref> He was still active after the [[October Revolution]], which placed Russia under a Bolshevik [[Council of People's Commissars]]. Slonim became an Eser candidate for the [[Russian Constituent Assembly]] in the [[Russian Constituent Assembly election, 1917|November 25 election]], running in the southwestern province of [[Bessarabia]].<ref>Constantin ''et al.'' (2011), p. 147; (2012), pp. 24, 391, 394, 404–406</ref> He took his seat in the Eser landslide win, and, aged 23, was the youngest parliamentarian.<ref name="krfreedom"/><ref>Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), p. 411; Aucouturier (1999), p. 379</ref><ref name="lbflamb">{{fr icon}} Laurent Béghin, [https://textyles.revues.org/2539 "La revue ''Le Flambeau'' et les littératures slaves (1918–1940)"], in ''Textyles'', No. 45, 2014</ref> Days after, Bessarabia formed its own government as the [[Moldavian Democratic Republic]], and remained undecided about its future within the [[Russian Republic]]. The elections for the Constituent Assembly were chaotic, and the results were never fully recorded.<ref>Clark, pp. 144–145</ref>
Slonim was present in the Assembly on the morning of January 19, 1918, when the Bolsheviks dissolved it by force and opened fire on the supporting crowds.<ref name="krfreedom"/> For a while, he was in the [[Ukrainian State]], helping [[Gregory Zilboorg]] put out a clandestine paper which angered both the Bolsheviks and the [[Ukrainian nationalism|Ukrainian nationalists]].<ref>Zilboorg & Slonim, pp. xix–xx</ref> He later fled to [[Samara, Russia|Samara]], where the Constituent Assembly had formed its own [[Committee of Members of the Constituent Assembly|"Committee of Members" government]]. He joined the latter, then, upon its merger into the [[Provisional All-Russian Government]], moved to [[Omsk]].<ref name="Aucouturier 1999, p. 379">Aucouturier (1999), p. 379</ref> As the [[Russian Civil War]] took hold of the countryside, Slonim followed the [[Czechoslovak Legion]] and became friends with its leaders,<ref name="Aucouturier 1999, p. 379"/> trailing across Siberia under an assumed name.<ref name="krfreedom"/> Nevertheless, he disliked the concept of [[Allied intervention in the Russian Civil War|Allied intervention]], and moved closer to the Left Esers. His party sent him abroad as a member of its Foreign Delegation, which originally existed to put persuade the West not to recognize [[Alexander Kolchak]] as Russia's Supreme Ruler.<ref>White, pp. 25–26</ref>
In November 1918, Slonim had lost his Bessarabian constituency, as the region [[Union of Bessarabia with Romania|united with Romania]]. The writer became a strong critic of that merger, claiming that the Romanian identity in both Romania and Bessarabia had been recently fabricated by intellectuals, lacking popular support among the Moldavian peasants (''see [[Moldovenism]]'').<ref name="White, p. 88">White, p. 88</ref> Slonim also claimed that the union process had been triggered by the [[German Empire]] in late 1917, as an anti-Bolshevik move, and supported by Russians who had discarded "personal and national dignity."<ref>White, p. 88. See also Clark, pp. 170–171</ref> Building on such arguments, Slonim depicted the Russian Empire as a functional and organic economic entity, suggesting that Bessarabia had more in common with Ukraine than with Romania.<ref name="White, p. 88"/>
He also argued that Bessarabia had not been renounced by Russia, not truly annexed by the [[Romanian Kingdom]]. "Sooner of later", he suggested, "there must come about [Bessarabia's] reunion with the Russian State."<ref>Clark, p. 236</ref> Acknowledging that there was a "united front" between the [[White movement]] and [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]] on the Bessarabian issue, he proposed to overcome the impasse by organizing a [[League of Nations]] referendum in the former Moldavian Republic.<ref>Clark, pp. 235–237</ref> Scholar [[Charles Upson Clark]], who sees Slonim's accounts as among "the best [...] from the Russian standpoint", rejects his theory about the German inspiration for the union, noting that it was in fact a traditional Romanian goal.<ref>Clark, pp. 166, 171</ref>
Slonim joined a self-appointed team of politicians and landowners who claimed to speak for Bessarabia, and attended the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]] to lobby for the Russian cause. Among the other members of this body were [[Alexander N. Krupensky]], [[Alexandr K. Schmidt]], [[Vladimir Tsyganko]], and [[Mihail Savenco]].<ref>Constantin ''et al.'' (2011), p. 147; (2012), pp. 391–394</ref> Slonim, seconded by Tsyganko, circulated rumors of "unheard-of atrocities" committed by the [[Romanian Army]], such as the massacre of 53 people in one village of [[Hotin County]], and the torturing of many others. Interviewed by ''[[L'Humanité]]'', the [[French Communist Party]] paper, Slonim also claimed the socialists were being repressed, and that unconditional union had been voted on "under the menace of machine guns".<ref>A. P., "Atrocités roumaines en Bessarabie. Le Récit de Marco Slonim, ex-député de la Constituante", in ''[[L'Humanité]]'', June 22, 1919, p. 3</ref> These statements were rejected outright by the Bessarabian unionists: [[Ion Inculeț]], the former [[President of Moldova|President of the Moldavian Republic]], called the interview "idiotic", while his aide [[Ion Pelivan]] wrote to ''L'Humanité'' to restate that the union was expressing the free will of the Bessarabian people.<ref>Constantin ''et al.'' (2011), p. 148</ref> In his notes, Pelivan referred to Slonim as a "deserter", an "impostor", and a [[History of the Jews in Belarus|Belarusian Jew]].<ref>Constantin ''et al.'' (2012), pp. 394, 404–406</ref>
===Tuscany, Berlin, and ''Volya Rossii''=== Slonim spent the years 1919–1922 in [[Tuscany]], becoming a regular contributor to the leftist daily ''[[Il Secolo]]''.<ref name="mlsrussi"/><ref name="csimigr343"/> In an article of August 1920, he opined that only "peace with Russia" and "the complete renunciation of all intervention into [her] internal affairs" could ensure the demise of "[[Soviet Empire|Bolshevist imperialism]]".<ref>''Bulletin Quotidien de Presse Étrangère'', No. 1530, August 21, 1920, p. 2</ref> That year, he published at H. Bemporad & figlio an Italian-language work on the revolutionary ideologies of [[Béla Kun]] and the [[Spartacus League]], eponymously titled ''Spartaco e Bela Kun'',<ref>[[Maffio Maffii]], "Notizie bibliografiche: Politica e problemi sociali", in ''L'Italia che Scrive'', Vol. IV, Issue 1, January 1921, p. 6</ref> and two memoirs: ''La rivoluzione russa'' ("The Russian Revolution"), and ''Il bolscevismo visto da un russo'' ("Bolshevism as Seen by a Russian").<ref name="mlsrussi"/> The latter was translated into French the following year, as ''Le Bolchévisme vu par un russe''. ''La Revue Critique des Idées et des Livres'' described it as "abundant in little facts from experience", a fresco "of the general misery, terror and fright that have been reigning in Russia for these past three years."<ref>J. M., "Les livres. Politique: ''Le Bolchévisme vu par un russe''", in ''La Revue Critique des Idées et des Livres'', Vol. XXXI, January–March 1921, p. 760</ref> His thoughts on communism brought him to the attention of [[Benito Mussolini]], leader of the [[Fasci Italiani di Combattimento|Fasci Italiani]], who invited Slonim to write for ''[[Il Popolo d'Italia]]''.<ref name="mlsrussi"/><ref name="csimigr343"/> Slonim explained that he would never write for the right-wing press; in a later reply, Mussolini insisted that his budding fascist movement was not in fact [[reactionary]].<ref name="csimigr343"/>
Another work, tracing the historical background of Bolshevism and the Esers, appeared in 1921 as ''Da Pietro il Grande a Lenin: Storia del movimento rivoluzionario in Russia'' ("From [[Peter the Great]] to Lenin: History of the Revolutionary Movement in Russia");<ref name="mlsrussi"/> a French edition came out in 1933, at [[Éditions Gallimard]].<ref>Livak (2010), p. 383</ref> Slonim followed up with an essay on Bolshevik [[Proletkult]] and [[Russian Futurism|Futurism]], taken up by [[Henri Grégoire (historian)|Henri Grégoire]]'s monthly, ''Le Flambeau'' (October 1921). At this early stage, Slonim derided Soviet literary productions, and described the better poets ([[Alexander Blok]] and [[Andrei Bely]]) as incompatible with communist dogmas.<ref name="lbflamb"/>
After a short stay in Berlin, during which time he issued his own journal, ''Novosti Literatury'',<ref name="mlsrussi"/><ref>Platone, p. 174</ref> Slonim settled in [[Prague]], [[First Czechoslovak Republic|Czechoslovakia]], where he taught at the Russian Free University<ref name="vcpaster">[http://newspaperarchives.vassar.edu/cgi-bin/vassar?a=d&d=miscellany19590218-01.2.6# "Slonim Views Pasternak's Philosophy in V.C. Lecture"], in ''Vassar Miscellany News'', Vol. XXXXIII, Issue 16, 1959</ref> and joined the local ''[[Zemgor]]''.<ref>White, p. 29</ref> He was also co-opted to write for the Russian-language émigré magazine ''Volya Rossii'' ("Russia's Will", "Russia's Freedom", or "Russia's Free Will"). Its editorial board included Slonim (editorial secretary to 1923, later full editor),<ref name="Aucouturier 1999, p. 379"/> [[Sergey Postnikov]], [[Evsei Stalinskii]], [[Vasily Sukhomlin]], and [[Vladimir Ivanovich Lebedev|Vladimir I. Lebedev]]. The former four were all members of the Eser Foreign Delegation; Lebedev was not.<ref>White, pp. 25, 96</ref>
Occupying a Prague building which had reputedly housed [[Mozart]], and also gathering for conversations at ''Národní kavárna'' café, the circle members networked with European policymakers such as [[Aristide Briand]], [[Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk]], and [[Émile Vandervelde]].<ref>White, pp. 28–29</ref> Although it published noted works of literature, including [[Marina Tsvetaeva]]'s ''Rat-Catcher'', ''Volya Rossii'' had a small readership.<ref>Angela Livingstone, "The Text and Publication", in [[Marina Tsvetaeva]], ''The Ratcatcher: A Lyrical Satire'', p. 32. Evanston: [[Northwestern University Press]], 1999. {{ISBN|0-8101-1816-5}}</ref> It depended largely on Czechoslovak government support, but the subsidies grew thinner by the year.<ref name="Aucouturier 1999, p. 389">Aucouturier (1999), p. 389</ref> Originally a daily in 1920, it became a weekly in 1922, and a monthly in 1923.<ref>Aucouturier (1999), p. 377; White, p. 20</ref>
From its relaunch in 1923, ''Volya Rossii'' was primarily noted as an exponent of the political left, and as such a rival of the more eclectic, Paris-based, ''[[Sovremennye Zapiski]]''. Its acceptance of various Bolshevik reforms made it close to the ''[[Mladorossi]]'' émigrés,<ref name="Aucouturier 1999, pp. 377–378">Aucouturier (1999), pp. 377–378</ref> but the magazine saw itself as eminently [[Narodniks|Narodnik]], carrying through the ideology of [[Alexander Herzen]] and [[Nikolay Chernyshevsky]].<ref>White, p. 20</ref> Beyond them, Slonim saw himself as a legatee of the [[Union of Salvation|Decembrists]].<ref name="Aucouturier 1999, p. 379"/> ''Volya Rossii'' was explicitly against the [[Constitutional Democratic Party|Kadet]] émigrés in Paris, and fought with their leader, [[Pyotr Struve]], for control over the Russian Free University.<ref>White, pp. 36–38</ref> It also took a secular approach to anti-communism, decrying the émigrés' debt to [[Russian Orthodox Church|Russian Orthodoxy]]—the church, Slonim asserted, was not a true foundation of Russian identity and culture.<ref>White, p. 33</ref> These positions were summarized in Slonim's sarcastic characterization of ''Sovremennye Zapiski'', a "non-partisan voice of the liberal-democratic broad front, with some tendencies that are sometimes socialist, sometimes religious."<ref>Renna, p. 23</ref>
===Literary columnist=== ''Volya Rossii'' stated its support for "[[Ethical socialism|moral socialism]]", relying on "the spontaneous activity and creativity of the masses."<ref name="Aucouturier 1999, pp. 377–378"/> While the group rallied around Slonim's ideas about Russian organicism and post-imperial federalism, it also firmly rejected expressions of [[Russian nationalism]], envisioning a Russia that rejected "all differences of faith, race or religion".<ref>White, pp. 87–88</ref> Slonim himself was a noted adversary of [[Eurasianism]] and theories of Russian exceptionalism, which understood Bolshevism as [[National Bolshevism|compatible with nationalist ideas]]. He interpreted Bolshevism as a "[[Jacobin (politics)|Jacobin]]" experiment in state control; he still believed in the regime's inevitable failure, and in the reemergence of democratic Russia.<ref>Dmitry Shlapentokh, "Thermidor or Mongol Empire. History as Political Model in Russian Émigré Thought", in ''Cahiers du Monde Russe et Soviétique'', Vol. 32, Issue 3, 1991, pp. 393, 406</ref> However, as he reported to [[Alexander Kerensky]], the Prague Esers feared the growth of the [[Communist Party of Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovakia's Communist Party]], which could turn on the émigré community.<ref>White, pp. 29–30</ref>
While contributing articles on political news and historical sketches, as well as impressions from a 1926 trip to the United States and a 1928 homage to Prague, Slonim became the main literary chronicler at ''Volya Rossii''.<ref>Aucouturier (1999), pp. 379–380</ref> He believed that the importance of [[Russian literature]] was to be found in its ability to convey "the vital problems of individual and social existence", and hoped that this tradition would be carried on in exile: "We know that the best among [émigré writers] made their way through suffering and struggle."<ref>Livak (2003), pp. 15–16</ref> Before 1925, Slonim focused his polemics on [[Zinaida Gippius]], whose articles in ''Sovremennye Zapiski'' prophesied the death of Russian literature. Chiding the "old guard" of Russian literati, he argued instead that modern literature was thriving both in Russia and in exile.<ref>Platone, pp. 182–183; Renna, pp. 24–25, 28</ref> From then on, Gippius came to regard Slonim with intense hostility, particularly since he also promoted Tsvetaeva, her personal enemy.<ref>Karlinsky, p. 160</ref>
While their [[Acmeist poetry|Acmeist]] rival [[Georgy Adamovich]] wanted to see through the emergence of a Russian [[psychological novel]], Slonim and [[Ivan Bunin]] believed that psychological introspection and [[social realism]] could still blend into a coherent whole: "spiritual vicissitudes had to be illustrated from the outside so that the reader could see them."<ref>Livak (2003), p. 101</ref> They urged émigrés to follow [[Modernist literature|modernist]] developments and replicate steps taken in Soviet literature. As a reviewer of Soviet works, Slonim identified echoes of the 19th-century philosophical and political epics, showing up in novels by [[Yevgeny Zamyatin]], [[Boris Pasternak]], [[Vsevolod Ivanov]] and [[Yury Olesha]].<ref>Aucouturier (1999), p. 382</ref> He looked with political optimism to the unfolding of the [[New Economic Policy]], which took Russia back to grassroots capitalism. Slonim searched for clues that communist writers were growing disenchanted with the Soviet state, and kept records about the "more tiresome and woeful" literature of [[agitprop]].<ref>Aucouturier (1999), pp. 386–387</ref>
In order to illustrate such points, ''Volya Rossii'' published fragments of works by Zamyatin, but also by [[Isaac Babel]] and [[Mikhail Sholokhov]], alongside [[Guillaume Apollinaire]] or [[Karel Čapek]].<ref>White, p. 32</ref> ''Volya Rossii'' soon patronized a generation of émigré modernists, beginning with Tsvetaeva and [[Aleksey Remizov]], followed later by [[Nina Berberova]], [[Dovid Knut]], [[Valentin Parnakh]], [[Vladimir Pozner]], [[Gleb Struve]], and [[Yuri Terapiano]].<ref>Aucouturier (1999), p. 380</ref> However, Slonim's encouragement had a perverse effect: in Russia, authors praised by Slonim or sampled in ''Volya Rossii'' were singled out as potential enemies of the regime. In 1927, the magazine hosted fragments from Zamyatin's novel ''[[We (novel)|We]]'', the first publication of that work in its original Russian.<ref name="krfreedom"/><ref>Zilboorg & Slonim, p. xx</ref> In order not to expose the author's direct contacts with the émigrés, Slonim claimed that these were back-translations from Czech and English reprints.<ref>Aucouturier (1999), p. 387; Zilboorg & Slonim, pp. xx–xxi</ref> Later, Slonim's positive reviews of ''[[Krasnaya Nov']]'' magazine were used against its editor, [[Aleksandr Voronsky]], who was eventually purged from the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Soviet Communist Party]].<ref>Robert A. Maguire, ''Red Virgin Soil: Soviet Literature in the 1920's'', p. 164. Evanston: [[Northwestern University Press]], 2000. {{ISBN|0-8101-1741-X}}</ref>
Slonim became a backer of Tsvetaeva and her husband [[Sergei Efron]], who had settled in Prague. Together with [[Salomeya Halpern]], [[Hélène Iswolsky]], [[D. S. Mirsky]] and Lebedev, he organized a Committee to Assist Marina Tsvetaeva.<ref>Feiler, p. 179</ref> He became a friend, confidant, and dedicated promoter of Tsvetaeva, even though she declined interest in Eser ideology and political matters in general.<ref name="krfreedom"/><ref>Feiler, pp. 125–126, 152–154, 189, 194–195, 240–241; Karlinsky, pp. 127, 160, 188, 201, 223–225, 250</ref> They continued to disagree over politics, whenever Tsvetaeva made a public show of her loyalty for the [[House of Romanov]].<ref>Feiler, pp. 125–126, 194–195</ref> Their liaison had romantic undertones: to Tsvetaeva, he was "the dear one", and his departure to be with another woman inspired her to write the poem "Attempt at Jealousy". Thinking that she held an idealized view of him, Slonim, newly separated from his first wife, rejected her advances in 1924, but they remained friends.<ref>Feiler, pp. 152–154</ref> He was critical of her affair with K. B. Rodzevitch, whom he regarded as a "dull, mediocre" man.<ref>Feiler, pp. 144–145</ref>
===Move to Paris=== By the late 1920s, Slonim had come to share Gippius' opinion that Russian literature in exile was doomed, its links with the Russian soil forever severed.<ref>Aucouturier (1999), pp. 378–379, 380; Livak (2003), pp. 33, 109</ref> He noted that, from 1926 on, the Foreign Delegation had only relied on Soviet publications for understanding the goings-on in Russia,<ref>White, pp. 41, 96, 113</ref> and argued that Soviet literature could be followed for its documentary value.<ref>Aucouturier (1999), p. 381</ref> He himself published an introduction to Russian literature in the 1927 edition of ''[[Slovanský Přehled]]''.<ref>"Cronique. Publications", in ''Revue des Études Slaves'', Vol. 8, Issue 1, 1928, p. 114</ref> His skepticism was also showing in his political essays, where he asserted that the Eser cause had been stifled by the [[1922 Moscow Trial of Socialist Revolutionaries|1922 Show Trials]].<ref>Marc Jansen, ''A Show Trial Under Lenin: The Trial of the Socialist Revolutionaries, Moscow 1922'', p. 177. The Hague etc.: [[Martinus Nijhoff Publishers]], 1982. {{ISBN|978-94-009-7608-5}}; White, pp. 96–101</ref> By then, the Esers' Prague group had become torn between two camps, each accusing the other of serving the Soviets. One was led by [[Viktor Chernov]], the other (comprising the ''Volya Rossii'' group) was headed by Sukhomlin.<ref>White, pp. 96–100</ref> Slonim also had a quarrel with writer [[Vasily Yanovsky]]—reportedly, because he commented on Yanovsky's poor use of Russian and his borrowings from [[Mikhail Artsybashev]].<ref>Livak (2003), p. 260</ref>
In 1927, Slonim purchased a printing press in Paris, where he hoped to relaunch ''Volya Rossii''.<ref name="Aucouturier 1999, p. 389"/> He ultimately abandoned the plan and, in 1928, simply relocated to Paris, together with Stalinskii and Sukhomlin.<ref name="White, p. 131">White, p. 131</ref> They reinforced a Russian colony that was just growing in importance, as French interest in Russian affairs was about to peak.<ref>Livak (2010), p. 22</ref> ''Volya Rossii'' continued to appear in Prague until March 1932,<ref name="Aucouturier 1999, p. 389"/> when it closed down as a result of the Chernov scandal.<ref>White, pp. 98, 130–131</ref> In its last years, it supported the [[Right Opposition]] and the [[first five-year plan|Five-Year Plan]], seeing them as evidence of Soviet normalization, and a promise for Eser uprisings. Lebedev even claimed to have traveled inside the Soviet Union.<ref>White, pp. 100–107, 128–130</ref> Slonim remained skeptical of this "mysticism", while also noting that the expanding [[Stalinism|Stalinist]] regime had emerged from industrialization as a "petty bourgeois" force, its appeal increased among émigré monarchists and Eurasianists.<ref>White, pp. 129–130</ref> His articles were regularly featured in other émigré publications: ''Sotsialist-Revolyutsioner'', ''Problemy'' and ''Novaya Gazeta'' in Paris; ''Russkiy Arkhiv'' of [[Belgrade]]; and the American ''Moskva''.<ref name="mlsrussi"/>
Slonim was focusing his attention on writing counter-propaganda descriptions of [[Socialist Realism]], which was entering the official Soviet literary and political discourse under [[Joseph Stalin]]. Readers of his work provide contrasting reviews: Aucouturier finds his 1930 study on ''Stalinism in Literature'' "important";<ref>Aucouturier (1999), p. 388</ref> however, according to the Russian sociologist Evgeny Dobrenko, Slonim's contribution here "overstep[s] the boundaries of scholarship."<ref>Evgeny Dobrenko, ''The Making of the State Writer: Social and Aesthetic Origins of Soviet Literary Culture'', p. 409. Stanford: [[Stanford University Press]], 2001. {{ISBN|0-8047-3364-3}}</ref> Although he still upheld the old Narodnik values, Slonim favored aestheticism and [[Russian formalism|formalism]] over [[social determinism]], and, on these grounds, criticized [[Pavel Milyukov]]'s work in literary history.<ref>Aucouturier (1999), pp. 381–384; Renna, pp. 26–29</ref> He also looked for tensions between the official dogma and writers who still cultivated individualism in its various forms, citing works by Pasternak,<ref>Renna, p. 31</ref> [[Artyom Vesyoly]], [[Yury Libedinsky]], and [[Leonid Leonov]].<ref>Aucouturier (1999), pp. 383–385, 388</ref> He welcomed Stalin's decision to disband the [[Russian Association of Proletarian Writers]], seeing it as a "Charter of Liberation" for the nonconformist authors.<ref>Schwartz, pp. 23–24</ref>
In Paris, Slonim set up his own literary society, ''Kochev'ye'' ("Camp of Nomads"), its name probably alluding to the [[Primitivism|primitivist]] aesthetics of the Left Esers.<ref name="Aucouturier 1999, p. 389"/> It held weekly session opposite [[Gare Montparnasse]], until 1938, when it dissolved.<ref name="mlsrussi"/> Like [[Nikolai Berdyaev]] and [[Nicholas Zernov]], Slonim also attached himself to the French Catholic circles, which welcomed Russian liberals who were at once anti-communist and anti-fascist.<ref>Livak (2010), p. 31</ref> He was also close to avant-garde painters [[Mikhail Larionov]] and [[Natalia Goncharova]], whom he introduced to Efron and Tsvetaeva when the latter couple also settled in Paris.<ref>Feiler, p. 192</ref> In 1933, he attended a symposium grouping ''Chisla'' magazine writers and members of the [[French Communist Party]], discussing [[André Gide]]'s account of life in the Soviet Union. The meeting veered into scandal when (according to Slonim's account) he took the rostrum and informed both camps that Gide was not in fact a convert to communism, and that "instead of making loud pronouncement they had better read Gide's oeuvre."<ref>Livak (2003), pp. 225–226</ref>
===Impresario and Soviet "defensist"=== Slonim's work diversified, and he became a literary impresario, founding, with [[George Reavey]], the European Literary Bureau. It had contracts with Berdyaev, [[Samuel Beckett]], [[André Malraux]] and [[Jacques Maritain]].<ref name="White, p. 131"/> He also worked on translations and on editing books for print: in 1930, [[Čestmír Jeřábek]]'s ''Svět hoří''; and in 1934, [[Adèle Hommaire de Hell]]'s ''Mémoires d'une aventurière''.<ref name="Livak 2010, p. 384">Livak (2010), p. 384</ref> Together with Reavey, he put out one of the first collections of Russian prose rendered in English (1934), which is also noted for its inclusion of Socialist Realists [[Alexander Fadeyev (writer)|Alexander Fadeyev]] and [[Feodor Gladkov]].<ref name="White, p. 131"/> With Gide's help,<ref>Livak (2010), p. 33</ref> Slonim and Reavey's anthology of Soviet literature came at Gallimard in 1935, and possibly included unsigned translations by Tsvetaeva.<ref>[[Robin Kemball]], "Barbarismes et «couleur locale» dans le lexique poétique de Blok. Essai d'analyse plurilingue", in ''Revue des Études Slaves'', Vol. 54, Part 4, 1982, p. 682</ref> Slonim was by then also publishing regular literary chronicles, turning his attention to works by [[William Faulkner]], [[Peter Neagoe]], and [[D. H. Lawrence]].<ref>Livak (2010), pp. 383–384</ref>
Slonim was for years critical of émigrés who asked to be resettled in the Soviet Union, denouncing Efron's work for the [[NKVD]]-sponsored [[Union for repatriation of Russians abroad|Union for Repatriation]].<ref>Feiler, p. 221</ref> In 1935, he finally met Zamyatin, who had escaped Russia, and they "became very good friends"—before Zamyatin's sudden illness and death.<ref>Zilboorg & Slonim, pp. xxii–xxv</ref> In 1934, Slonim had resumed his conferencing on Lenin, networking with Italian anti-fascists such as [[Oddino Morgari]] and [[Alberto Meschi]], and being followed around by Mussolini's [[OVRA]].<ref name="mlsrussi"/>
Slonim and Lebedev became alarmed by the rise of [[Nazi Germany]], and predicted that it would attack the Soviet Union with support from the right-wing exiles. With this in mind, they founded in 1936 a Russian Émigré Defensist Movement (REOD), its newspaper edited by Slonim.<ref>White, pp. 133–135</ref> Slonim came to agree with the basic tenets of Soviet thinking: he believed that democracy was doomed, and that the world was becoming split into two camps, of communism and fascism.<ref>White, pp. 134–135, 138</ref> He formulated his preference into a [[Soviet socialist patriotism|socialist-patriotic]] manifesto: "The defensist joyfully greets all tidings of the internal and external successes of Russia. When a new factory is built in the Soviet Union, when a strong army is created, when a heroic ﬂight is made, when important discoveries are made and when a talented book is written, the defensist feels a sense of pride."<ref name="White, p. 134">White, p. 134</ref>
He put out in 1935 a sympathetic book on the ill-fated expedition of [[SS Chelyuskin|''SS'' Chelyuskin]], followed in 1937 by ''Les onzes républiques soviétiques'' ("The Eleven [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet Republics]]"), at [[Éditions Payot]].<ref>Livak (2010), pp. 383, 384; White, p. 134</ref> The latter book was well-liked in the Soviet Union itself, and recommended by [[Intourist]],<ref name="White, p. 134"/> but criticized by [[Pierre (Piotr) Pascal|Pierre Pascal]] for its geographical and historical inaccuracies.<ref>[[Pierre (Piotr) Pascal|Pierre Pascal]], "Notes bibliographiques. U.R.S.S.: Marc Slonim, ''Les onzes républiques soviétiques''", in ''[[Revue Historique]]'', Vol. 182, June 1938, p. 393</ref> In 1938, Slonim also translated [[Viktor Shklovsky]]'s ''Voyage de Marco Polo''.<ref name="Livak 2010, p. 384"/> However, he had grown more appreciative of the ''Sovremennye Zapiski'' writers, and in 1939, published generous commentary on [[Vladimir Nabokov]]'s work, beginning with ''[[King, Queen, Knave]]''.<ref>Paul Duncan Morris, ''Vladimir Nabokov: Poetry and the Lyric Voice'', p. 393. Toronto etc.: [[University of Toronto Press]], 2010. {{ISBN|978-1-4426-4020-7}}</ref> That year, Slonim also completed a version of Bunin's ''Liberation of [[Leo Tolstoy|Tolstoy]]'', published by Gallimard but disliked by the author.<ref>Livak (2010), pp. 39, 95</ref>
When Lebedev abandoned the REOD and moved to America in 1936, Slonim continued his work. This was an especially controversial decision, as the REOD became exposed for its links with the Union for Repatriation and the NKVD. Slonim ultimately presented his resignation in July 1938.<ref>White, pp. 135, 137–138</ref> In June 1939, he met Tsvetaeva one final time in Paris, as she and Efron began their return trip to the Soviet Union.<ref>Feiler, pp. 240–241</ref> Slonim was still in Paris after the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact|Nazi–Soviet Pact]] and before the [[Battle of France|Nazi invasion of France]]. Arrested for his contacts with the French communists, he was sent to a French concentration camp.<ref name="White, p. 138">White, p. 138</ref> By August 1941, he was in Spain, taking the [[SS Navemar|SS ''Navemar'']] from [[Seville]] to New York City. He completed the journey, despite the ''Navemar''{{'}}s "criminally inadequate" facilities, alongside friends [[Zosa Szajkowski]] and [[Mark Zborowski]].<ref>Lisa Moses Leff, ''The Archive Thief: The Man Who Salvaged French Jewish History in the Wake of the Holocaust'', pp. 72–73. Oxford etc.: [[Oxford University Press]], 2015. {{ISBN|978-0-19-938095-4}}</ref>
===Sarah Lawrence College=== Slonim initially lectured on Russian topics at [[Yale College|Yale]], [[University of Chicago|Chicago]] and [[University of Pennsylvania|Penn]], before becoming, in 1943, a professor of Russian and [[comparative literature]] at [[Sarah Lawrence College]], [[Yonkers, New York|Yonkers]].<ref name="vcpaster"/> While publishing various pieces in American academic journals,<ref name="vcpaster"/> Slonim also contributed to the Jewish cultural review ''Yevreiski Mir''. In a 1944 article for that magazine (quoted favorably by scholar Simon Markish),<ref>Simon Markish, "À propos de l'histoire et de la méthodologie de l'étude de la littérature juive d'expression russe", in ''Cahiers du Monde Russe et Soviétique'', Vol. 26, Issue 2, 1985, pp. 140–141</ref> he denied the existence of a separate [[Jewish literature]] in Russia, proposing that Jewish authors were merely Russian authors. His stance in this far-reaching debate about [[Jewish assimilation]] was similar to that of his uncle Aykhenvald, including their proposed reference to Jewish writers as "writers who are Jews".<ref>Shrayer, pp. xliii, xlvii–xlviii</ref> In late 1944, he lectured at the [[Phillips Academy]] East and West Association on the issue of [[Russia–United States relations]].<ref>J.R.W.D., "General School Interests. East and West Lectures Series", in ''The Phillips Bulletin'', Vol. 39, Issue 3, 1945, pp. 11–12</ref>
Slonim was viewed with caution by the American Esers. They investigated his REOD activity and concluded that he had shown callousness, and had mixed with NKVD envoys, but cleared him of allegations that he had been a spy himself.<ref>White, pp. 135, 138</ref> Following the [[Operation Barbarossa|Nazi attack on the Soviet Union]], Slonim and his colleagues, reunited in New York City, resumed the "defensist" line, unconditionally; Chernov took a more moderate stance.<ref name="White, p. 138"/> In February 1945, Slonim finally met Nabokov at a dinner party in New York. Nabokov dismissed him as a Soviet agent, and probably used him as an inspiration for the novella ''Double Talk''.<ref name="boyd85"/> Nabokov's reading is dismissed by his exegetes: Vladimir E. Alexandrov speaks of Nabokov's "unjustified suspicions, including his snubbing of Marc Slonim";<ref>Vladimir E. Alexandrov, ''The Garland Companion to Vladimir Nabokov'', p. 627. New York City & Oxon: [[Routledge]], 1995. {{ISBN|0-8153-0354-8}}</ref> [[Brian Boyd]] also notes that Slonim "was in fact firmly against Stalin and the Soviet system."<ref name="boyd85"/> Before 1950, Slonim was again banned in the Soviet Union and the [[Eastern bloc]]: copies of ''Le Bolchévisme vu par un russe'' were confiscated on sight by the [[Ministry of Communications and Information Society (Romania)|Romanian Propaganda Ministry]].<ref>"Comunicate și circulări ministeriale. Ministerul informațiunilor", in ''[[Monitorul Oficial]]'', March 25, 1947, p. 2262</ref>
In 1950, [[Oxford University Press]] released Slonim's literary panorama, ''The Epic of Russian Literature from Its Origins Through Tolstoy''. According to the ''Revue des Études Slaves'', it was an "intelligent and alert" work, appealing "to the cultivated public rather than the specialists". ''The Epic'', echoing the approach of [[Eugène-Melchior de Vogüé]], focused on the 19th-century novels and debates, being more dismissive of earlier literature.<ref>"Cronique. Publications", in ''Revue des Études Slaves'', Vol. 29, Issue 1, 1952, p. 175</ref> He followed up in 1953 with a second volume, ''Modern Russian Literature'', covering the period from [[Anton Chekhov]] to the 1950s,<ref name="Aucouturier p. 411"/> and a biographical study, ''Tri lyubi Dostoyevskogo'' ("Three Loves of [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky|Dostoevsky]]").<ref name="mlsrussi"/><ref name="Aucouturier p. 411"/><ref name="krfreedom"/><ref name="vcpaster"/> He returned to Italy on a research trip, employed by [[Sapienza University of Rome|La Sapienza University]]'s Institute for Slavic Philology, and, in 1954, edited the collection ''Modern Italian Short Stories''.<ref name="mlsrussi"/> In 1954, at the height of [[McCarthyism]], he appeared before the [[United States Senate Subcommittee on Internal Security|Jenner Committee]], dismissing rumors of communist activities at Sarah Lawrence.<ref name="krfreedom"/>
Additionally, Slonim worked with [[Harvey Breit]] on a [[New American Library|Signet]] anthology of love stories, which appeared in 1955 as ''This Thing Called Love''.<ref>Rochelle Girson, "Time for a Little More 'Yin'", in ''[[Tampa Bay Times|St. Petersburg Times]]'', October 2, 1955, p. 13</ref> In 1959, he lectured at [[Vassar College|Vassar]] on Pasternak's philosophical outlook.<ref name="vcpaster"/> A year later, he commemorated Pasternak by moderating a round table for [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|Radio Liberty]]. Guests included Reavey, [[B. J. Chute]], [[Herbert Gold]], [[Ferenc Körmendi]], and [[Santha Rama Rau]].<ref>Sosin, pp. 87–88</ref> Also in 1960, he collected and edited for print selections from [[Mikhail Zoshchenko]]'s satires (as ''Izbrannoe'').<ref name="mlsrussi"/> In parallel, he arranged for print the diaries of [[Leonid Andreyev]]. That project was put on hold by son [[Vadim Andreyev]], for fear that disclosing his father's opinions on Bolshevism would make the ban on his work permanent.<ref>Yuri Leving, Frederick H. White, ''Marketing Literature and Posthumous Legacies. The Symbolic Capital of Leonid Andreev and Vladimir Nabokov'', pp. 44–47, 96, 97. Lanham & Plymouth: [[Lexington Books]], 2013. {{ISBN|978-0-7391-8260-4}}</ref>
===Final years=== According to Aucouturier, Slonim stands out as "one of the first independent critics of the USSR's literary output [and] a pioneer of Soviet literary historiography in the Occident."<ref name="Aucouturier 1999, p. 389"/> Italian writer [[Italo Calvino]], who visited Sarah Lawrence College in 1959, called Slonim "the most famous expert on Russian literature in America".<ref>[[Italo Calvino]], ''Hermit in Paris: Autobiographical Writings'', p. 41. New York City: [[Mariner Books]], 2014. {{ISBN|978-0-544-14669-3}}</ref> Philologist Melissa Frazier sees him as an "incredibly significant figure in the phenomenon of Russian émigré culture". She notes: "Slonim did a lot more in the way of plot summary—but in the polarized world of the Cold War, even plot summary was hugely important. [...] He was one of the few in the West actually reading what was being written in the Soviet Union with the recognition that there were still great writers who had stayed behind."<ref name="krfreedom"/>
Slonim retired from Sarah Lawrence in 1962, and from teaching in 1965, living the rest of his life in Switzerland, where he was animator of a Russian literary club.<ref>Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), p. 411; Aucouturier (1999), p. 389</ref> In 1963–1964, from his new home in [[Geneva]], Slonim worked on an English version of [[Andrei Bely]]'s ''Silver Dove'', and corresponded over literary details with Maria Olsufyeva, who had finished translating that same novel into Italian.<ref>Stefania Pavan, ''Le carte di Marija Olsuf'eva nell'Archivio contemporaneo Gabinetto G. P. Vieusseux'', pp. 13–15. Rome: Edizioni di storia e letteratura, 2002. {{ISBN|88-8498-025-9}}</ref> Slonim's last standalone book was the 1964 textbook ''Soviet Russian Literature. Writers and Problems'', praised by ''Revue des Études Slaves'' for its "sense of balance", but criticized for its "allusive nature".<ref>José Johannet, "Chronique: Publications. Russe", in ''Revue des Études Slaves'', Vol. 45, Parts 1–4, 1966, p. 279</ref> Social historian Lawrence H. Schwartz notes its "vitriolic" critique of the [[Union of Soviet Writers]].<ref>Schwartz, pp. 24–25</ref>
Slonim also contributed regularly to reviews and encyclopedias, answering queries posed by his younger colleagues,<ref>Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), pp. 411–412</ref> and supporting the Sarah Lawrence graduate program in Switzerland.<ref name="krfreedom"/> Some of his final articles defended a fellow critic, [[Andrei Sinyavsky]], who had angered the Soviet establishment with his reading of [[Alexander Pushkin]].<ref name="Aucouturier p. 411"/> In late 1968, he staged a letter writing campaign in support of the Soviet writer-dissident [[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn]].<ref>Sosin, p. 124</ref> His historical essay on ''Volya Rossii'' was published in 1972, as part of Nikolai Poltoratsky's review of Russian literature in exile.<ref>Karlinsky, p. 265; Renna, p. 23</ref> He also arranged for print [[Sofiya Pregel]]'s ''Last Poems'' (1973).<ref>Shrayer, p. 479</ref>
Slonim died in 1976 in the French resort of [[Beaulieu-sur-Mer]].<ref name="mlsrussi"/> His incomplete memoirs, covering the period up to October 1917, were handed by his widow, Tatiana, to Aucouturier, who published them in ''Cahiers du Monde Russe et Soviétique''.<ref>Aucouturier & Slonim (1977), p. 412</ref> Tatiana Slonim continued to live in Geneva. In 1986, she donated her husband's 16th-century copy of the ''[[Theotokos of Vladimir]]'' to the city's [[Musée d'Art et d'Histoire (Geneva)|Art and History Museum]].<ref>{{fr icon}} Marielle Martiniani-Reber, [http://blog.mahgeneve.ch/la-vierge-de-vladimir-du-musee-dart-et-dhistoire/ ''La Vierge de Vladimir du Musée d'art et d'histoire''], [http://blog.mahgeneve.ch/ MAH blog], August 15, 2013; retrieved October 12, 2015</ref>
