{{pp-semi|small=yes}}
'''Online dating''' (or '''Internet dating''') is a system that enables people to find and introduce themselves to new personal connections over the [[Internet]], usually with the goal of developing personal, romantic, or sexual relationships. An '''online dating service''' is a company that provides specific mechanisms (generally websites or applications) for online dating through the use of Internet-connected [[personal computer]]s or mobile devices. Such companies offer a wide variety of [[Moderation system|unmoderated]] [[matchmaking]] services, most of which are profile-based.
Online dating services allow users to become "members" by creating a profile and uploading personal information including (but not limited to) age, gender, sexual orientation, location, and appearance. Most services also encourage members to add photos or videos to their profile. Once a profile has been created, members can view the profiles of other members of the service, using the visible profile information to decide whether or not to initiate contact. Most services offer digital messaging, while others provide additional services such as [[webcast]]s, [[online chat]], telephone chat ([[Voice over Internet Protocol|VOIP]]), and [[message boards]]. Members can constrain their interactions to the online space, or they can arrange a [[dating|date]] to meet in person.
A great diversity of online dating services currently exists. Some have a broad membership base of diverse users looking for many different types of relationships. Other sites target highly specific demographics based on features like shared interests, location, religion, or relationship type. Online dating services also differ widely in their revenue streams. Some sites are completely free and depend on advertising for revenue. Others utilize the [[freemium]] revenue model, offering free registration and use, with optional, paid, premium services.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2011/12/13/badoo-unveils-features-to-help-shy-users-flirt/|title=Badoo Unveils Features to Help Shy Users Flirt|date=2011-12-13|publisher=Mashable.com|author=Brian Anthony Hernandez 7|accessdate=2012-07-17}}</ref> Still others rely solely on paid membership subscriptions.
Opinions and usage of online dating services also differ widely. A 2005 study of data collected by the [[Pew Internet & American Life Project]] found that individuals are more likely to use an online dating service if they use the Internet for a greater number of tasks, and less likely to use such a service if they are trusting of others.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kang|first=Tanya|year=2011|title=Why Would You Decide to Use an Online Dating Site? Factors That Lead to Online Dating|journal=[[Communication Research Reports]]|volume=28|issue=3|page=205|doi=10.1080/08824096.2011.566109|author2=Lindsay H. Hoffman}}</ref> It is possible that the mode of online dating resonates with some participants' conceptual orientation towards the process of finding a romantic partner. That is, online dating sites use the conceptual framework of a "marketplace metaphor" to help people find potential matches, with layouts and functionalities that make it easy to quickly browse and select profiles in a manner similar to how one might browse an online store. Under this metaphor, members of a given service can both "shop" for potential relationship partners and "sell" themselves in hopes of finding a successful match.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Heino|first=R.|author2=N. Ellison |author3=J. Gibbs |title=Relationshopping: Investigating the market metaphor in online dating.|journal=[[Journal of Social and Personal Relationships]]|volume=27|issue=4|year=2010|pages=427–447 |doi=10.1177/0265407510361614}}</ref>
== Trends == === Social trends === [[File:Smartphone dating app illustration.jpg|thumb|Since the 2010s, Internet dating has become more popular with smartphones.]] At the end of November 2004, there were 844 lifestyle and dating sites, a 38% increase since the start of the year, according to Hitwise Inc. The stigma associated with online dating dropped over the years and people view online dating more positively.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/02/29/5-facts-about-online-dating/|title=5 facts about online dating|date=2016-02-29|work=Pew Research Center|access-date=2017-04-02|language=en-US}}</ref> The 2006 [[Pew Internet & American Life Project]] on Online Dating noted an increase in usage of online dating sites by Americans to pursue their romantic interests.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.pewinternet.org/2006/03/05/online-dating/|title=Online Dating|last=Madden|first=Mary|last2=Am|date=2006-03-05|website=Pew Research Center: Internet, Science & Tech|access-date=2017-04-01|last3=Lenhart|first3=a}}</ref> About one in ten respondents reported visiting these online dating websites.<ref name=":0" /> In 2005–2012, about 34.95% of Americans reported meeting their spouses online.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Modern Romance|publisher = Penguin Press|date = 2015-06-16|isbn = 978-1-59420-627-6|first = Aziz|last = Ansari|first2 = Eric|last2 = Klinenberg}}</ref> The 2016 Pew Research Center's survey reveals that the usage of online dating sites by American adults increased from 9% in 2013, to 12% in 2015. Further, during this period, the usage among 18- to 24-year-olds tripled, while that among 55- to 65-year-olds doubled.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.pewinternet.org/2016/02/11/15-percent-of-american-adults-have-used-online-dating-sites-or-mobile-dating-apps/|title=15% of American Adults Have Used Online Dating Sites or Mobile Dating Apps|last=Smith|first=Aaron|date=2016-02-11|website=Pew Research Center: Internet, Science & Tech|access-date=2017-04-01}}</ref>
Online daters may have more liberal social attitudes compared to the general population in the United States.<ref name=twsDecH19h>{{cite news |first1=Mary |last1=Madden |first2=Amanda |last2=Lenhart |title= Online Dating: Americans who are seeking romance use the internet to help them in their search, but there is still widespread public concern about the safety of online dating |publisher= ''Pew Internet & American Life Project'' |quote= Online daters tend to identify with more liberal social attitudes, compared with all Americans or all internet users. |date= September 2005 |url= http://www.pewinternet.org/Reports/2006/Online-Dating/05-Who-Is-Dating-Online/04-Online-daters-tend-to-identify-with-more-liberal-social-attitudes.aspx?r=1 |accessdate= 2010-12-08 }}</ref> According to a 2015 study by the [[Pew Research Center]], 80% of the users, and 55% of non-users, said that online dating sites are a good way to meet potential partners.<ref name=":1" /> In addition, respondents felt that online dating is easier, more efficient than other methods, and gives access to a larger pool of potential partners.<ref name=":1" /> Increased dating and marriage outside traditional social circles may be a contributing factor to coincident societal changes, including rising rates of interracial marriage.<ref name=":2">{{cite arxiv|last=Ortega|first=Josue|last2=Hergovich|first2=Philipp|date=2017|title=The Strength of Absent Ties: Social Integration via Online Dating|eprint=1709.10478|class=physics.soc-ph}}</ref> On the other hand, about 45% respondents felt that online dating is more dangerous compared to other methods.<ref name=":1" /> Views on online dating were similar across genders, with women expressing more concerns about safety than men.<ref name=":1" />
==== Niche dating sites ==== Sites with specific demographics have become popular as a way to narrow the pool of potential matches.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/HEALTH/04/14/finding.love.online/|title=Finding love online, despite health problems – CNN.com|date=2010-04-14|work=CNN|accessdate=2010-05-20}}</ref> Successful niche sites pair people by race, sexual orientation or religion.<ref name="newyorktimes">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/27/fashion/27niche.html?_r=1&ref=fashion&oref=slogin|title=Let's Say You Want to Date a Hog Farmer|last=Sullivan|first=J. Courtney|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2006-04-28}}</ref> In March 2008, the top 5 overall sites held 7% less market share than they did one year ago while the top sites from the top five major niche dating categories made considerable gains.<ref name="techcrunch">{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2008/04/24/niche-dating-sites-grow-steadily-as-mainstream-ones-flail/|title=Niche Dating Sites Grow Steadily As Mainstream Ones Flail|publisher=Tech Crunch|accessdate=2006-04-24}}</ref> Niche sites cater to people with special interests, such as sports fans, racing and automotive fans, medical or other professionals, people with political or religious preferences (e.g., Hindu, Jewish, Christian, Muslim, etc.), people with medical conditions (e.g., HIV+, obese), or those living in rural farm communities.
==== Online introduction services ==== In 2008, a variation of the online dating model emerged in the form of introduction sites, where members have to search and contact other members, who introduce them to other members whom they deem compatible. Introduction sites differ from the traditional online dating model, and attracted a large number of users and significant investor interest.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2008/06/12/speed-dating-site-woome-raises-125m-more-on-41m-valuation/|title=Speed-dating site WooMe raises $12.5M more, enjoys $41M valuation|date=2008-06-12|publisher=VentureBeat|accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref>
=== Economic trends === Since 2003, several free dating sites, operating on ad based-revenue rather than monthly subscriptions, have appeared and become increasingly popular.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}} Other partially free online dating services offer only limited privileges for free members, or only for a brief period.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}} Although some sites offer free trials and/or profiles, most memberships can cost upwards of $60 per month.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realsimple.com/work-life/money/cost-comparison-internet-dating-sites-00000000028239/index.html|title=Cost Comparison: Internet Dating Sites|publisher=realsimple.com|accessdate=2013-03-17}}</ref>
In 2008, online dating services in the United States generated $957 million in revenue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.computerworld.com/online_dating_its_bigger_than_porn|title=Online dating: It's bigger than porn – Computerworld Blogs|date=2009-02-13|publisher=Computer World|accessdate=2014-01-02|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102193659/http://blogs.computerworld.com/online_dating_its_bigger_than_porn|archivedate=2014-01-02|df=}}</ref>
In Eastern Europe, popular sites offer full access to messaging and profiles, but provide additional services for pay, such as prioritizing profile position, removing advertisements, and giving paying users access to a more advanced search engine. Such sites earn revenue from a mix of advertising and sale of additional options. This model also allows users to switch between free and paying status at will, with sites accepting a variety of online currencies and payment options.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}}
Most free dating websites depend on [[advertising]] revenue, using tools such as [[Google AdSense]] and [[affiliate marketing]]. Since advertising revenues are modest compared to membership fees, this model requires a large number of [[page view]]s to achieve profitability. However, [[Sam Yagan]] describes dating sites as ideal advertising platforms because of the wealth of demographic data made available by users.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time100.time.com/2013/04/18/time-100/slide/sam-yagan/|title=Sam Yagan | TIME 100: The 100 Most Influential People in the World | TIME.com|last=Levitt|first=Steven|date=2013-04-18|publisher=Time100.time.com|accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref>
== Controversy == === Trust and safety === There are mixed opinions regarding the safety of online dating. Over 50% of research participants in a 2011 study did not view online dating as a dangerous activity, whereas 43% thought that online dating involved risk.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Couch | first1 = Danielle | last2 = Liamputtong | first2 = Pranee | last3 = Pitts | first3 = Marian | year = 2011 | title = Online Daters and the Use of Technology for Surveillance and Risk Management | url = | journal = International Journal of Emerging Technologies & Society | volume = 9 | issue = 2| pages = 116–134 }}</ref> Because online dating takes place in virtual space, it is possible for profile information to be misrepresented or falsified. While some sites conduct [[background check]]s on members, many do not, resulting in some uncertainty around members' identities. For instance, some profiles may not represent real humans but rather "bait profiles" placed online by site owners to attract new paying members, or "spam profiles" created by advertisers to market services and products.
Profiles created by real humans also have the potential to be problematic. For example, online dating sites may expose more female members in particular to [[stalking]], [[fraud]], and [[sexual violence]] by [[online predator]]s.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} A less malicious form of misrepresentation is that members may lie about their height, weight, age, or marital status in an attempt to market or brand themselves in a particular way.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.linkedin.com/today/post/article/20140316230919-1288829-when-personal-branding-get-too-personal|title=When personal branding get too personal! Online dating and your brand.|date=March 16, 2014|publisher=Linkedin|last1=Jones|first1=Cher}}</ref> Users may also carefully manipulate profiles as a form of [[impression management]].<ref name="Couch 2008">{{cite journal|last=Couch|first=Danielle|year=2008|title=Online Dating and Mating: The Use of the Internet to Meet Sexual Partners|journal=Qualitative Health Research|author2=Pranee Liamputtong}}</ref> Online dating site members may try to balance an accurate representation with maintaining their image in a desirable way.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ellison|first=Nicole|year=2006|title=Managing impressions online: Self-presentation processes in the online dating environment|journal=Journal of Computer-Mediated Communication|volume=11|issue=2|pages=415–441|doi=10.1111/j.1083-6101.2006.00020.x|author2=Rebecca Heino|author3=Jennifer Gibbs}}</ref> One study found that nine out of ten participants had lied on at least one attribute, though lies were often slight; weight was the most lied about attribute, and age was the least lied about.<ref name="Hancock 2007">{{cite journal|last=Hancock|first=Jeffrey|year=2007|title=The truth about lying in online dating profiles}}</ref> Furthermore, knowing a large amount of superficial information about a potential partner's interests may lead to a false sense of security when meeting up with a new person.<ref name="Williams">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/13/fashion/the-end-of-courtship.html?pagewanted=all|title=The End of Courtship|last=Williams|first=Alex|date=2013-01-11|publisher=The New York Times}}</ref> Gross misrepresentation may be less likely on [[matrimonial website|matrimonials sites]] than on casual dating sites.<ref name=":0" /> Some dating services have been created specifically for those living with HIV and other STIs in an effort to eliminate the need to lie about one's health in order to find a partner.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2012|title=An ethics of intimacy: Online dating, viral-sociality and living with HIV|url=http://www.research.ed.ac.uk/portal/files/16366431/2012_Mazanderani_Ethics_of_intimacy_author_final.pdf|journal=BioSocieties|volume=7|issue=4|pages=393–409|doi=10.1057/biosoc.2012.24|author=Mazanderani, F.}}</ref>
Media coverage of crimes related to online dating may also contribute to perceptions of its risks.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} However, online dating may also have advantages over conventional (offline) dating in that it offers unprecedented access to potential partners for singles who otherwise would not have such access.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://psi.sagepub.com/content/13/1/3.full?ijkey=cK9EB6/4zQ0AM&keytype=ref&siteid=sppsi|title=Online Dating : A Critical Analysis From the Perspective of Psychological Science|journal=Psychological Science in the Public Interest|volume=13|issue=1|pages=3–66|last=Finkel et. al.|first=Eli.J.|access-date=|doi=10.1177/1529100612436522|pmid=26173279|year=2012}}</ref>
The emergence of dating sites that promote adultery, such as [[Ashley Madison]], has stirred some controversy. Marriage breakups happened in about 6% of online couples, compared to 7.6% of offline ones.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} Mean marital satisfaction scores were 5.64 and 5.48 for the online and offline couples, respectively.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}}{{Original research inline|date=July 2017}}
=== Billing ===
Online subscription-based services can suffer from complaints about billing practices. Some online dating service providers may have fraudulent membership fees or credit card charges.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.muckrock.com/news/archives/2013/mar/21/bad-romance-online-dating-complaints-made-ftc/|title=Bad romance: Online dating complaints made to the FTC|website=MuckRock|accessdate=2015-12-14}}</ref> Some sites do not allow members to preview available profiles before paying a subscription fee. Furthermore, different functionalities may be offered to members who have paid or not paid for subscriptions, resulting in some confusion around who can view or contact whom.
Consolidation within the online dating industry has led to different newspapers and magazines now advertising the same website [[database]] under different names. In the UK, for example, [[Time Out (company)|''Time Out'']] ("London Dating"), ''[[The Times]]'' ("Encounters"), and ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' ("Kindred Spirits"), all offer differently named portals to the same service—meaning that a person who subscribes through more than one publication has unwittingly paid more than once for access to the same service.
=== Imbalanced gender ratios ===
On any given dating site, the [[human sex ratio|sex ratio]] is commonly unbalanced. A website may have two women for every man, but they may be in the 35+ range, while the men are generally under 35.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} Little is known about the sex ratio controlled for age. [[eHarmony]]'s membership is about 57% female and 43% male,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Compare Online Dating Site reviews and prices at NextAdvisor.com|url = http://www.nextadvisor.com/online_dating/compare.php|website = www.nextadvisor.com|accessdate = 2015-12-14}}</ref> whereas the ratio at [[Match.com]] is about the reverse of that. When one gets into the specialty niche websites where the primary demographic is male, one typically gets a very unbalanced ratio of male to female or female to male.<ref>[http://www.brandchannel.com/careers_profile.asp?cr_id=53 Brandchannel.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012200213/http://brandchannel.com/careers_profile.asp?cr_id=53 |date=2007-10-12 }}. Retrieved 21 November 2007.</ref>
Studies have suggested that men are far more likely to send messages on dating sites than women.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Cupid on Trial: An OKCupid Online Dating Experiment|url = http://jonmillward.com/blog/attraction-dating/cupid-on-trial-a-4-month-online-dating-experiment/|website = Jon Millward|accessdate = 2015-12-14|language = en-US|date = 2012-06-19}}</ref> In addition, men tend to message the most attractive women regardless of their own attractiveness.<ref>{{Cite journal|title="Where Have All the Good Men Gone?" Gendered Interactions in Online Dating|journal = Journal of Marriage and the Family|date = 2014-04-01|issn = 0022-2445|pmc = 4043335|pmid = 24910472|pages = 387–410|volume = 76|issue = 2|doi = 10.1111/jomf.12072|first = Derek A.|last = Kreager|first2 = Shannon E.|last2 = Cavanagh|first3 = John|last3 = Yen|first4 = Mo|last4 = Yu}}</ref> This leads to the most attractive women on these sites receiving an overwhelming number of messages, which can in some cases result in them leaving the site.
There is some evidence that there may be differences in how women online rate male attractiveness as opposed to how men rate female attractiveness. The distribution of ratings given by men of female attractiveness appears to be the [[normal distribution]], while ratings of men given by women is highly skewed, with 80% of men rated as below average.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.okcupid.com/index.php/2009/11/17/your-looks-and-online-dating/|title=Your Looks and Your Inbox|author=Christian Rudder|work=OkTrends}}</ref> This shows that women are genuinely more picky than men when it comes to appearance on online dating websites.
=== Discrimination === [[Gay rights]] groups have complained that certain websites that restrict their dating services to heterosexual couples are discriminating against [[homosexuals]]. Homosexual customers of the popular [[eHarmony]] dating website have made many attempts to litigate discriminatory practices.<ref>{{cite news|last=Buss|first=Dale|title=Discordant Voices Among eHarmony.com's Customers|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB122782471897362521|accessdate=31 October 2013|newspaper=Wall Street Journal – Eastern Edition|date=28 November 2008}}</ref> eHarmony was sued in 2007 by a [[lesbian]] claiming that "[s]uch outright discrimination is hurtful and disappointing for a business open to the public in this day and age."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/2007-06-01-eharmony-suit-discrimination_N.htm|title=Woman sues eHarmony for discrimination – USATODAY.com|publisher=}}</ref> In light of discrimination by sexual orientation by dating websites, some services such as [[Gaydar (website)|GayDar.net]] and [[Chemistry.com]] cater more to homosexual dating.
Less than half of Internet daters are open to dating people of all races.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Yancey|first=George|title=Cross racial differences in the racial preference of potential dating partners|journal=[[The Sociological Quarterly]]|volume=50|year=2009|pages=121–143|doi=10.1111/j.1533-8525.2008.01135.x}}</ref> Consistent with the [[Social exchange theory#Applications|social exchange]] and [[social position|group position]] theories, Asians, Latinos and blacks are more open to dating whites than whites are to dating them. Of those who state a racial preference, 97% of white men exclude black women, 48% exclude Latinas, and 53% exclude Asian women. In contrast, white men are excluded by 76% of black women, 33% Latinas, and only 11% Asian women. Similarly, 92% of white women exclude black men, 77% exclude Latinos, and 93% exclude Asian men. 71% of black men, 31% of Latinos, and 36% of Asian men excluded white women.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Robnett|first=Belinda|last2=Feliciano|first2=Cynthia|date=2011-05-04|title=Patterns of Racial-Ethnic Exclusion by Internet Daters|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/430702|journal=Social Forces|volume=89|issue=3|pages=807–828|doi=10.1353/sof.2011.0008|issn=1534-7605}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|first1=Cynthia|last1=Feliciano|first2=Belinda |last2=Robnett|first3=Golnaz|last3=Komaie|year=2009|title=Gendered Racial Exclusion Among White Internet Daters|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/26333132|journal=Social Science Research|volume=38|issue=1|pages=39–54|via=|doi=10.1016/j.ssresearch.2008.09.004|pmid=19569291}}</ref>
== Lawsuits filed against online dating services == A 2011 class action lawsuit alleged [[Match.com]] failed to remove inactive profiles, did not accurately disclose the number of active members, and does not police its site for fake profiles;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wfaa.com/story/money/consumer/2014/08/10/13658956/|title=Popular dating Web site sued for using fake profiles|date=4 January 2011|publisher=WFAA TV}}</ref> the inclusion of expired and spam profiles as valid served to both artificially inflate the total number of profiles and camouflage a skewed gender ratio in which active users were disproportionately single males.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/news/2011/01/04/matchcom-customers-sue-their-matchmaker.html|title=Customers sue Match.com|date=4 January 2011|work=Dallas Business Journal}}</ref> The suit claimed up to 60 percent were inactive profiles, fake or fraudulent users.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cio.com/article/2412313/internet/match-com-sued-by-sour-love-seekers.html|title=Match.Com Sued By Sour Love Seekers|author=John P. Mello Jr.|date=5 January 2011|work=CIO}}</ref> Some of the spam profiles were alleged to be using images of porn actresses, models, or people from other dating sites.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20110114/09203212668/matchcom-sued-over-deadfake-profiles.shtml|title=Match.com Sued Over Dead/Fake Profiles|work=Techdirt.}}</ref> Former employees alleged Match routinely and intentionally over-represented the number of active members on the website and a huge percentage were not real members but 'filler profiles'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kens5.com/story/local/2014/10/01/10770267/|title=Match.com website sued for using fake profiles|date=10 November 2013|publisher=KENS TV 5}}</ref>
A 2012 class action against [[Successful Match]] ended with a November 2014 [[California]] jury award of $1.4 million in compensatory damages and $15 million in punitive damages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2014/11/05/successfulmatch_dating_site_has_to_pay_after_sharing_users_sti_statuses.html|title=SuccessfulMatch dating site has to pay after sharing users' STI statuses.|work=Slate Magazine|date=2014-11-05}}</ref> SuccessfulMatch operated a dating site for people with STDs, [[PositiveSingles]], which it advertised as offering a "fully anonymous profile" which is "100% confidential".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2013/07/24/major-dating-service-faces-legal-action-for-allegedly-sharing-hiv-and-std-statuses-of-customers|title=Major Dating Service Faces Legal Action for Allegedly Sharing HIV and STD Statuses of Customers|author=Elizabeth Flock|work=US News & World Report}}</ref> The company failed to disclose that it was placing those same profiles on a long list of affiliate site domains such as GayPozDating.com, AIDSDate.com, HerpesInMouth.com, ChristianSafeHaven.com, MeetBlackPOZ.com, HIVGayMen.com, STDHookup.com, BlackPoz.com, and PositivelyKinky.com.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.outandaboutnashville.com/story/hiv-positive-dating-website-faces-class|title=HIV-Positive dating website faces class action lawsuit for allegedly sharing HIV status of users|work=Out & About Nashville|date=2013-07-29}}</ref> This falsely implied that those users were black, Christian, gay, HIV-positive or members of other groups with which the registered members did not identify.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tcattorney.typepad.com/techlaw/2012/01/successfulmatchcom-class-action-filed-alleging-unfair-competition-and-californias-consumers-legal-re.html|title=Positive Singles and Successful Match Class Action Filed, Alleging Unfair Competition and California's Consumers Legal Remedies Act (CLRA)|publisher=TC Attorney}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.herpes-dating.com/law-suit-alleging-positive-singles-of-violating-privacy-norms-shows-the-dating-site-in-negative-light/|title=Law suit alleging Positive Singles of violating privacy norms shows the dating site in negative light|publisher=Herpes Dating}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aaronkellylaw.com/internet-law/class-action-john-doe-lawsuit-filed-against-internet-dating-network/|title=Class Action John Doe Lawsuit – Positive Singles – Internet law|publisher=Aaron Kelly law firm}}</ref> The jury found PositiveSingles guilty of fraud, malice, and oppression<ref>http://www.courthousenews.com/2014/11/03/PositiveSingles%20State.pdf</ref> as the plaintiffs' race, sexual orientation, HIV status, and religion were misrepresented by exporting each dating profile to niche sites associated with each trait.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xbiz.com/news/187220|title=Jury Finds STD-Positive Dating Site Liable for $16.5M in Damages|author=XBIZ|work=XBIZ}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/business/dating-website-data-privacy/|title=Dating site for people with STIs must pay millions for violating privacy|work=The Daily Dot|date=2014-11-05}}</ref>
In 2013, a former employee sued adultery website [[Ashley Madison]] claiming repetitive strain injuries as creating 1000 fake profiles in one three week span "required an enormous amount of keyboarding" which caused the worker to develop severe pain in her wrists and forearms.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/ashley-madison-adultery-website-sued-by-former-employee-1.2421819|title=Ashley Madison adultery website sued by former employee|date=10 November 2013|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref> AshleyMadison's parent company, [[Avid Life Media]], [[countersue]]d in 2014, alleging the worker kept confidential documents, including copies of her "work product and training materials." The firm claimed the fake profiles were for "quality assurance testing" to test a new Brazilian version of the site for "consistency and reliability."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ashley-madison-adultery-website-countersues-ex-employee-1.2583359|title=Ashley Madison adultery website countersues ex-employee|date=23 March 2014|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref>
In January 2014, an already-married [[Facebook]] user attempting to close a pop-up advertisement for Zoosk.com found that one click instead copied personal info from her Facebook profile to create an unwanted online profile seeking a mate, leading to a flood of unexpected responses from amorous single males.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/facebook-info-sharing-created-zoosk-com-dating-profile-for-married-woman-1.2844953|title=Facebook info sharing created Zoosk.com dating profile for married woman|date=24 November 2014|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC News]]|first=Rosa|last=Marchitelli}}</ref>
In 2014, [[It's Just Lunch International]] was the target of a New York class action alleging [[unjust enrichment]] as IJL staff relied on a uniform, misleading script which informed prospective customers during initial interviews that IJL already had at least two matches in mind for those customers' first dates regardless of whether or not that was true.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/14/us-itsjustlunch-lawsuit-idUSBREA4D0RF20140514|title=It's Just Lunch to face U.S. class-action lawsuit over matchmaking claims|work=Reuters | date=2014-05-14}}</ref>
In 2014, the US [[Federal Trade Commission]] fined UK-based [[JDI Dating]] (a group of 18 websites, including Cupidswand.com and FlirtCrowd.com)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/dating-site-fined-for-posting-fake-profiles/|title=Dating site fined for posting fake profiles|work=CNET}}</ref> over [[US dollar|US$]]600000, finding that "the defendants offered a free plan that allowed users to set up a profile with personal information and photos. As soon as a new user set up a free profile, he or she began to receive messages that appeared to be from other members living nearby, expressing romantic interest or a desire to meet. However, users were unable to respond to these messages without upgrading to a paid membership ... [t]he messages were almost always from fake, computer-generated profiles — 'Virtual Cupids' — created by the defendants, with photos and information designed to closely mimic the profiles of real people."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2014/10/online-dating-service-agrees-stop-deceptive-use-fake-profiles|title=Online Dating Service Agrees to Stop Deceptive Use of Fake Profiles|publisher=US Federal Trade Commission|date=2014-10-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2014/10/29/359901518/online-dating-site-used-fake-profiles-to-get-members-to-upgrade-service|title=Online Dating Site Used Fake Profiles To Get Members To Upgrade Service|date=29 October 2014|work=NPR.org}}</ref> The FTC also found that paid memberships were being renewed without client authorisation.
In 2017 Darlene Daggett, QVC's president for U.S. commerce from 2002 to 2007, filed a lawsuit against matchmaking agency Kelleher International.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Collman|first1=Ashley|title=Former QVC executive, 62, sues reality show matchmaker|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4774926/Retired-executive-sues-matchmaking-company-paid-150k.html|accessdate=18 September 2017|publisher=Daily Mail|date=9 August 2017}}</ref> The company, owned by Amber Kelleher-Andrews agreed to settle within hours of Daggett filing the lawsuit. Neither talked about the case, citing a non-disclosure agreement, but Daggett's lawsuit gives plenty of detail about her grievances with the California-based company. 'Due to her senior level position in a local firm, [she] felt that social dating sites did not provide her with the degree of screening and privacy she was looking for,' the lawsuit states. She opted in for the company's most expensive plan, the $150,000 CEO level, which guaranteed her matches from around the world and the personal attention of Kelleher-Andrews. But Daggett says she did not get what she paid for. Instead, she suffered brief romantic entanglements with increasingly disastrous men.
== Government regulation == U.S. government regulation of dating services began with the [[International Marriage Broker Regulation Act]] (IMBRA)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uscis.gov/USCIS/Laws/Memoranda/Static_Files_Memoranda/Archives%201998-2008/2006/imbra072106.pdf |title=International Marriage Broker Regulation Act Implementation Guidance – HQOPRD 70/6.2.11 |publisher=[[U.S. Department of Homeland Security]] |date=July 21, 2006 |author=Aytes, Michael |accessdate=2012-11-11}}</ref> which took effect in March 2007 after a federal judge in Georgia upheld a challenge from the dating site European Connections. The law requires dating services meeting specific criteria—including having as their primary business to connect U.S. citizens/residents with foreign nationals—to conduct, among other procedures, sex offender checks on U.S. customers before contact details can be provided to the non-U.S. citizen. In 2008, the state of New Jersey passed a law which requires the sites to disclose whether they perform background checks.<ref name="MSNBC">{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/23117392/|title=Background checks split online dating industry – Technology & science – Security – msnbc.com|date=2008-02-12|publisher=MSNBC|accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref>
In the [[People's Republic of China]], using a transnational matchmaking agency involving a monetary transaction is illegal.<ref>{{cite web|author=马玉佳 |url=http://www.china.org.cn/china/2011-08/30/content_23312519.htm |title=Transnational matchmaking illegal in China |publisher=China.org.cn |date=2011-08-30 |accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref> The [[Philippines]] prohibits the business of organizing or facilitating marriages between Filipinas and foreign men under the [[Philippine Republic Act 6955|Republic Act 6955]] (the Anti-Mail-Order Bride Law) of June 13, 1990; this law is routinely circumvented by basing [[mail-order bride]] websites outside the country.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KzhEUE35pRcC&pg=PA103 |title=Trafficking And the Global Sex Industry |publisher= |accessdate=2013-04-16|isbn=9780739113134 |author1=Beeks |first1=Karen |last2=Amir |first2=Delila |year=2006 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=muPfQjYP-0IC&pg=PA55 |title=Romance on a Global Stage: Pen Pals, Virtual Ethnography, and "Mail-Order Brides" |author=Nicole Constable |publisher= |date=2003-08-19 |accessdate=2013-04-16|isbn=9780520937222 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Mae Ryan |title=Imported Filipino brides share the ups and downs of settling in America |url=http://www.scpr.org/programs/offramp/2012/09/26/28576/imported-filipino-brides-settle-into-love-in-south/ |newspaper=SCPR |date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=9 December 2014 }}</ref>
Singapore's [[Social Development Network]] is the governmental organization facilitating dating activities in the country. Singapore's government has actively acted as a matchmaker for singles for the past few decades, and thus only 4% of Singaporeans have ever used an online dating service, despite the country's high rate of internet penetration.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}}
In December 2010, a [[New York State]] Law called the "Internet Dating Safety Act" (S5180-A) went into effect that requires online dating sites with customers in New York State to warn users not to disclose personal information to people they do not know.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.internetdatingconference.com/new-york-senate-bill-S5180a-internet-dating-safety-act.php|title=S5180-A|publisher=Internetdatingconference.com|accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref>
== In popular culture == * ''[[You've Got Mail]]'', a 1998 film in which the two protagonists conduct a relationship entirely over e-mail before meeting each other. * ''[[Jewtopia]]'', a comedic play about Jewish stereotypes and dating, premiered in 2003. * ''[[Napoleon Dynamite]]'', a 2004 film in a which one subplot involves a central character's online (and later in-person) relationship. * ''[[Euro Trip]]'', a 2004 film in which the central character has a relationship wholly via email with a girl from Berlin. * ''[[Must Love Dogs]]'', a 2005 film about two people trying to find love through online dating. * ''[[Because I Said So (film)|Because I Said So]]'', a 2007 film in which a mother creates an online dating profile for her daughter. * ''[[Sex Drive (film)|Sex Drive]]'', a 2008 film about a young man who goes on a cross-country roadtrip with friends to meet his internet crush, and woo her with his brother's stolen GTO. * ''[[Love Translated]]'', a 2010 documentary film in which a group of men travel to Ukraine on a romantic tour arranged by an online dating company * ''[[Catfish: The TV Show]],'' a reality TV-show that premiered on MTV in 2012. * "[[Hang the DJ (Black Mirror)|Hang the DJ]]", aired in December 2017, an episode in the fourth series of [[Black Mirror]] about a futuristic dating app.

The term '''physics envy''' is a phrase used to criticize modern writing and research of academics working in areas such as "[[soft sciences|softer sciences]]", [[liberal art]]s, business studies and humanities.{{cite web|last1=Clarke|first1=Kevin|last2=Primo|first2=David|title=Overcoming ‘Physics Envy’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/01/opinion/sunday/the-social-sciences-physics-envy.html|website=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=10 August 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Sokal|first1=Alan|title=Physics envy in psychology: A cautionary tale|url=http://www.physics.nyu.edu/sokal/CCNY_lecture_Nov_19_15.pdf|publisher=[[New York University]]|accessdate=10 August 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Bennis|first1=Warren|last2=O'Toole|first2=James|title=How Business Schools Lost Their Way|url=https://hbr.org/2005/05/how-business-schools-lost-their-way|website=[[Harvard Business Review]]|accessdate=10 August 2016}} The term argues that writing and working practices in these disciplines have overused confusing [[jargon]] and complicated mathematics, in order to seem more 'rigorous' and like mathematics-based subjects like physics.{{cite book|author=Robin Dunbar|title=The Trouble with Science|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5HbvQsET6zIC&pg=PA214|date=7 April 2011|publisher=Faber & Faber|isbn=978-0-571-26519-0|pages=214–231}}{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Noah|title=Academic B.S. as artificial barriers to entry|url=http://noahpinionblog.blogspot.co.uk/2015/12/academic-bs-as-artificial-barriers-to.html|website=Economics, neologisms, and distraction|accessdate=10 August 2016}} ==Background== The success of physics in "mathematicizing" itself, particularly since [[Isaac Newton]]'s ''[[Principia Mathematica (Newton)|Principia Mathematica]]'', is generally considered remarkable and often disproportionate compared to other areas of inquiry.For example, [[Eugene Wigner]] remarked "The miracle of the appropriateness of the language of mathematics for the formulation of the laws of physics is a wonderful gift which we neither understand nor deserve.", while [[Richard Feynman]] said "To those who do not know mathematics it is difficult to get across a real feeling as to the beauty, the deepest beauty, of nature ... If you want to learn about nature, to appreciate nature, it is necessary to understand the language that she speaks in." "Physics envy" refers to the envy (perceived or real) of scholars in other disciplines for the mathematical precision of fundamental concepts obtained by physicists. It is an accusation raised against disciplines (typically against [[social sciences]] and [[liberal art]]s such as [[literature]], [[philosophy]], and [[psychology]]) when these academic areas try to express their fundamental concepts in terms of mathematics, which is seen as an unwarranted push for [[reductionism]]. [[Evolutionary biology|Evolutionary biologist]] [[Ernst Mayr]] discusses the issue of the inability to reduce biology to its mathematical basis in his book ''What Makes Biology Unique?''.Mayr (2004) [[Noam Chomsky]] discusses the ability and desirability of reduction to its mathematical basis in his article "Mysteries of Nature: How Deeply Hidden."Chomsky (2009) Chomsky contributed extensively to the development of the field of [[theoretical linguistics]], a [[formal science]]. ==See also== *[[Newtonianism]] *[[Philosophy of biology]] *[[Philosophy of physics]] *[[Philosophy of science]] *[[Reductionism]] *[[Unreasonable ineffectiveness of mathematics]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{cite journal |last=Chomsky |first=N. |year=2009 |title=The Mysteries of Nature: How Deeply Hidden? |url=http://www.journalofphilosophy.org/articles/106/106-4.htm |journal=[[Journal of Philosophy]] |volume=106 |issue= 4 |pages=167–200 |doi= }} ** Collected in {{cite book |title=Chomsky Notebook |editors=Jean Bricmont and Julie Franck |chapter=1. The Mysteries of Nature: How Deeply Hidden? |year=2010 |isbn=978-0-231-14475-9}} *{{cite book |last=Csikszent |first=M. |last2=Hektner |first2=J.M. |last3=Schmidt |first3=J.A. |year=2006 |title=Experience Sampling Method: Measuring the Quality of Everyday Life |publisher=[[SAGE Publications]] |isbn=978-1-4129-4923-1 }} *{{cite book |last=Mayr |first=E. |year=2004 |title=What Makes Biology Unique? Considerations on the Autonomy of a Scientific Discipline |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn=978-0-521-84114-6 }} *{{cite book |last=Mirowski | first=P. |year=1999 |title=More Heat Than Light |chapter=The Ironies of Physics Envy |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn=0-521-42689-8 }} *{{cite book |last=Schabas |first=M. |year=1993 |chapter=What's So Wrong with Physics Envy? |editor=de Marchi, N. |title=Non-Natural Social Science |page=45 |publisher=[[Duke University Press]] |isbn=0-8223-1410-X }} *{{cite book |last=Schram |first=S. |last2=Caterino |first2=B. |year=2006 |title=Making Political Science Matter: Debating Knowledge, Research, and Method |publisher=[[New York University Press]] |isbn=978-0-8147-4033-0 }} ==External links== *[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/01/opinion/sunday/the-social-sciences-physics-envy.html Overcoming ‘Physics Envy’], [[op-ed]] by two political scientists. [[New York Times]], published March 30, 2012 *[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203430404577094760894401548 Physics Envy: "quants" and financial models], essay and book review of ''Models Behaving Badly'' by [[Emanuel Derman]]. Review by [[Burton Malkiel]], WSJ, December 14, 2011 *[http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1563882] Andrew Lo (MIT Sloan School) and Mark Mueller (MIT Sloan School and MIT Center for Theoretical Physics), "Warning: Physics Envy May be Hazardous to Your Wealth!" published in the Journal of Investment Management, Volume 8, Number 2, Second Quarter 2010 [https://www.joim.com/abstract.asp?IsArticleArchived=1&ArtID=354]

{{About|the publishing company|the novels by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn|The Red Wheel}} {{refimprove|date=December 2011}} {{Infobox publisher | image = | parent = | status = | founded = 1956 | founder = Samuel Weiser | successor = | country = United States | headquarters = [[Newburyport, Massachusetts]] | distribution = self-distribution (US)
Georgetown Publications (Canada)
Brumby Sunstate (Australia)
[[Hay House]] (South Africa)
Deep Books (Europe)
Curreri World Services (Asia)[http://redwheelweiser.com/downloads/17b_trade_final_sm.pdf Red Wheel/Weiser Featuring Conari Press and Hampton Roads New Titles and Best-Selling Backlist, Fall 2017] | keypeople = | publications = Books | topics = | genre = New Age, occult | imprints = Red Wheel, Weiser Books, Conari Books, Disnformation Books, Turning Stone Press, Career Press, New Page Books | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | url = {{URL|redwheelweiser.com}} }} '''Red Wheel Weiser Conari''', also known in different periods in its history as '''RedWheel/Weiser, LLC''' and '''Samuel Weiser, Inc.''', is a book [[publisher]] with three [[imprint (trade name)|imprint]]s: Red Wheel, Weiser Books and Conari Books. It is America's second-largest{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}} [[publisher]] of [[occult]] and [[New Age]] books, behind [[Llewellyn Worldwide]], and is also one of the oldest American publishers to concentrate exclusively on that [[genre]]. It publishes on average 60-75 new titles per year and maintains a large [[backlist]], partly of books that it originally published, and partly of older [[public domain]] rare occult books. ==Imprints== ===Weiser Books=== This main imprint is also the oldest. It was founded as ''Samuel Weiser, Inc.'' in 1956, a time when few other publishers were willing to tackle occult subjects, and was originally an offshoot of the New York City retailer, [[Weiser Antiquarian Books]]. This imprint publishes the backlist and continues to acquire books on occultism, [[astrology]], [[esoteric]] subjects, Eastern religions, [[Wicca]] and related topics. ===Red Wheel=== Red Wheel was founded in 2000 as an imprint for spiritually oriented or occult [[self-help]] and [[how-to]] books, and at that time the company name was changed from Samuel Weiser, Inc. to RedWheel/Weiser, with several other variations being commonly seen, including Weiser, Inc. ===Conari Books=== This imprint was acquired in 2002. Before this, Conari Books had been a separate publisher, based in [[Berkeley, California]], dating back to 1989. This imprint focuses on books that view [[sociology]] and [[parenting]] issues through a spiritual or New Age perspective. ===Turning Stone Press=== Turning Stone was founded in 2012. It is a self-publishing imprint in collaboration with [[Hampton Roads Publishing Company]] and Hierophant Publishing.{{Cite web| title = Red Wheel/Weiser Enters Self Publishing with Turning Stone Press| work = PublishersWeekly.com| accessdate = 2017-12-01| url = https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/50394-red-wheel-weiser-enters-self-publishing-with-turning-stone-press.html}} ===Disinformation Books=== Disinformation Books was founded in 1997 as the publishing division of [[Disinformation (company)|Disinformation]]. It was acquired by Red Wheel/Weiser in 2012.{{Cite web| title = Red Wheel Weiser Buys Disinformation Books| work = PublishersWeekly.com| accessdate = 2017-12-01| url = https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/book-deals/article/52226-red-wheel-weiser-buys-disinformation-books.html}} ===Career Press=== Career Press was founded in 1985 by Ron Fry and is focused on business books. Red Wheel/Weiser acquired Career Press in 2017.{{Cite web| title = Red Wheel Buys Career Press, Hires Peter Turner| work = PublishersWeekly.com| accessdate = 2017-12-01| url = https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/industry-deals/article/75235-red-wheel-buys-career-press-hires-peter-turner.html}} ===New Page Books=== New Page Books was founded in 1999 as the general nonfiction imprint of Career Press. ==Location== The company has been previously located in [[Boston]] and in [[York Beach, Maine]] for most of its history. In 2006, the editorial department moved to [[San Francisco]] and the sales and marketing department moved to [[Newburyport, Massachusetts]]. ==Famous authors== *[[Aleister Crowley]] *[[Dion Fortune]] *[[Eliphas Levi]] *[[S.L. MacGregor Mathers]] *[[Arthur Edward Waite]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *''2007 Writer's Market'', Robert Lee Brewer & Joanna Masterson. (2006) {{ISBN|1-58297-427-6}} *''Jeff Herman's Guide To Book Publishers, Editors & Literary Agents 2007'', Jeff Herman. (2006) {{ISBN|0-9772682-1-7}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.redwheelweiser.com/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Red Wheel Weiser Conari}} [[Category:New Age]] [[Category:Neopagan media]] [[Category:Book publishing companies based in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Occult books]] [[Category:Publishing companies established in 1956]] [[Category:Companies based in Newburyport, Massachusetts]]

Hartlib]]<ref name="O'Brien1965">{{cite journal|last1=O'Brien|first1=John J.|title=Samuel Hartlib's influence on Robert Boyle's scientific development|journal=Annals of Science|volume=21|issue=4|year=1965|pages=257–276|issn=0003-3790|doi=10.1080/00033796500200141}}</ref>}} [[Katherine Jones, Viscountess Ranelagh|Katherine Boyle Jones]] |influenced = [[Isaac
